review: 4.5 stars. Excellent read. Very much a product of its time and yet shockingly contemporary. Made me feel like the 1930s were closer to today's way of thinking than the post-war era. He was extremely open minded on many topics, from religion to work. Enjoyable hearing old time stories of FDR, Lincoln, Franklin and many more. Great ideas for getting along in the world with more joy and less trouble. My main criticisms are: 1) his treatment of gender and 2) his theory of change. On gender, the book is full of stories of sexual harassment in the workplace and mansplaining. That's agitating. Second, I don't think Dale Carnegie has any conception of the struggle to change society, particularly as a white privileged man. Society just worked for him. For blacks and other minorities, for women, for gay people, the world is full of bias and prejudice. How best to handle this? Often, I think Carnegie's approach is correct. You can catch more flies with honey. But other times, I think we should consider our theories of how change happens, and recognize that struggle, criticism and resistance are necessary. In short, very thought provoking and fun read. Especially the old-timey audiobook reader. Highly recommended! I'm surprised to say that! But it's a fun book, full of wisdom. And it's less about manipulation than kindness, understanding, listening and taking others' perspective into account.
It's a good book that include useful tips for influence people. Also has lots of influential and memorable quotes in it and easy-to-read.

My grandfather, the most affable person I've ever met, swore by Dale Carnegie's books. This is the first that I have read and I find it to be quite helpful. Sometimes I refer to parts of it to remind myself to apply them in my daily life. The title may sounds pretentious, or like something only a salesperson or politician would read, but it's really helpful just for how a person interacts with other people. I have had problems with social anxiety, and I find that thinking about some of Carnegie's methods helps me handle social situations by concentrating on being genuinely interested in what people have to say rather than how awkward I feel.Bottom Line: How to Win Friends and Influence People can help pretty much anyone interact with his or her peers more effectively.
I have this audio book and yes, you CAN have the jobs you want!

I read this after a friend said he had read it and said what was written was fairly self-explanatory. Yes, it is self-explanatory for some people, and yes, some of the book seems to be outdated, but overall, the principles conveyed and backed up with examples are good tenets for anyone to have a refresher on: be kind, and others will be kind to you. We all have our struggles. Let's remember that.

Went through this book again (audio book). Honestly, didnt like it as much as i liked when i first read it. But it reinforced one fact- the basics of dealing with humans wont drastically change- no matter how much technology invades our lives.

No earth shattering new insights, but a good collection of tips. Everybody will definitely learn at least one thing from this book. The fast smooth narrative and unique anecdotes explain why this book has stood the test of time.

Dale Carnegie provides a practical guide to speak and to influence people by developing your speaking skills. Who does not want to develop? Who does not want to be influential? Neither do I. This is not only a personal development book, but will help you as well when you want to improve your abilities as a business person. I did like this book very well, and it will help me very well to develop myself in business life and personal life. I am glad that revisions were made to fit the current world, and I will probably read this book again in the upcoming few months!

I finally read it. Probably one of the most influential business books. I can see why it lives on. It's packed with actual tips for how to be liked and listened to--and who doesn't want that? It's nice that each tip is brought to life with a few cases, but there's a whole lot of movie magic happening in these scenarios: the antagonist always says and reacts in exactly the right way to create an outcome. The value nevertheless is provided in the reveal of these techniques. The bonus comes that they're productive to society on the whole. The catch is that the way that they're applied is the only thing that matters; and genuinely, tactfully, effectively employing them is much easier said than done. Important read, though.
Amazing book and provides insight on how to look from others perspective.This will stand as one of the best book for me and will refer it in between.

In some ways, the material in this book is dated; however, the underlying message is timeless: It's the golden rule--treat others as you would want to be treated.You may want to be less verbose in how you execute the principles presented, but the advice is still sound.

The book is rather readable and relevant dispite having been written in 1936 and since it is a classic you will at least be getting some cultural knowledge out of reading it.

I enjoyed this book thoroughly, and let me put it this way. I spend the past decade educating myself, completing a masters degree, working hard, reading, engaging in heavy discussions. When I started school and work, I remember thinking with my intellect, I want to bring about a change in the world. NOTHING WORKED!! I could have all the knowledge and the drive in this world to want to make a difference but without the fundamental knowledge on how to work with people, how to influence others and work effectively through arguments, I realized I will not succeed. This is an easy book to discount. There is the slogan that the title has become. Many of the examples seem outdated at first, from the early 20th century, and the narrative sounds naive in today's highly skeptical social atmosphere. In addition, the lessons seem somewhat simple. I bought this book on a whim while I was browsing through a bookstore in the Hasidic neighborhood while vacationing in Brooklyn, curious about what the locals would be reading. So more just to see what happened than not, I decided to start trying to apply some of the advice Carnegie was offering up. I was amazed to see that these bits of advice actually did work. I realized that much of this I actually already knew but didn't want to apply because I thought those ideas were beneath me. So long after he wrote the book despite its outmoded style and examples, it's a great read and a great guide to dealing well with people. I'm glad I succumbed to the whim and now I'll use these lessons for all my life.

A lot of the points reminds us that wherever you are, you are dealing with people, and politeness goes a long long way. When you've been working a long time, you see people being impolite (and rude) in the name of familiarity. It may not be the boo for everyone, but as a reader, I think it is a good read.

This is a book I've been slowly processing for the better part of a year now. The ideas it contains are simple, and it all basically boils down to "be nice, see things other people's way, and then exploit what they want".At times I felt like the techniques were almost a little dirty, given that Carnegie is essentially asking everyone to exploit the human psyche. For example, rather than address a problem directly, you are supposed to butter up the other person, make them feel important, bow to their every need, and then they'll do what you want. I guess you can't argue with the results, but some of the things in the book just felt icky.That said, the book contains good advice on what makes people tick and gives good ideas on how to make people like you. It's a good read that will add one more feather in your cap to help you navigate your job, your friends, and your family relationships.
Still good advice decades after it was written. It would be interesting to see the family tree of self-help books; I'd bet that this little book (a quick read) is near the root.

Each chapter has interesting stories and lessons from history about how men and women have been successful in life and business. (A lot of the stories are from Lincoln and Teddy Roosevelt, who are 2 of my favorite men of history). In each chapter, Carnegie drives home a simple point that would be useful in day to day interactions. Some of the points are as simple as being genuinely happy about seeing people and seeking to avoid arguments at all costs. That being said, none of the author's points are mind-blowing in themselves; however, I found it quite useful to see how I can improve in my relations with others. I would certainly recommend this book to any of my friends. You have nothing to lose and a whole lot to gain by reading this book.

This is such a hopeful little book. At some point in your life, someone who is trying to seem nice while actually acting superior will hand you this book. They will tell you that you absolutely have to read it and it will change your life. So you will. What you will find is a really nice, optimistic take on the world from a guy who just generally had a good attitude. You will not see the underlying white and male privilege, but it is there. None of the things that happened to the author would have happened if he was, say, a black female. And yet, it is uplifting and really a good read if you ignore the obvious flaws.

A book that contrary to its title, encourages people to be less manipulative, more genuine and positive in nature. Carnegie relates his golden nuggets of wisdom through telling real-world stories of people in everyday situations. I feel that his 12 principles say it all.1. The only way to win an argument is to avoid one2. Show respect for the other persons opinion, never say "you are wrong"3. If you are wrong admit it quickly and emphatically4. Begin in a friendly way5. Get the other person saying "yes yes" immediately6. Get the other person to do a great deal of talking7. Let the other person feel that the idea is their own8. Try honestly to see from the other persons point of view9. Be sympathetic with the other persons ideas and desires10. Appeal to the nobler motives11. Dramatize your ideas12. Throw down a challenge On being a leader:1 Begin with praise and honest appreciation2. Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly3. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing others4. Ask questions instead of giving direct orders5. Let the other person save face6. Be lavish in your praise7. Give the person a fine reputation to live up to8. Make the fault seem easy to correct9. Make the person happy about doing the thing you suggest

Just finished reading "How to Win Friends and Influence People" (2006) by Dale Carnegie. Perhaps the most well-known self-help book of all time, I decided to borrow it and understand Carnegie's most popular book that serves as influence for many other modern self-help books.If the book's contents seem familiar, it's because the book was originally written back in 1936. Carnegie's book details the basic skills of communication that are common sense in terms of dealing with people, yet are underutilised by many people. His words of wisdom are simplistic, and he preaches values of empathy, humility, patience and understanding so that readers can become better people.The lessons in the book are backed up purely by anecdotes that the author has personally heard from the people he has come across during his lifetime. More story-based than scientific, his writing style reflects the kind of person Carnegie is: a hardworking boy from Missouri who experienced many failures and setbacks in his career, but had a knack for public speaking and soon got his huge break and became the most influential self-help coach of all time.Though the contents and writing style are understandably dated, his lessons are anything but obsolete. They serve as timeless morals that everyone can benefit and learn to apply in daily life. I thank the man who perhaps would not understand the sheer importance of his own book even to this day.NEXT BOOK: "The Art of Work" (2015) by Jeff Goins.

I finally read this book cover to cover, even though it has been sitting on our shelves for years & I have skimmed through it a few times. It was worth the read. In fact, I've decided I need to read it about once a year.The title sounds like it's a book on how to manipulate people, and since it was originally published in 1937, it is terribly dated in an interesting sort of way. However, the principles are fantastic - basically the Golden Rule broken down into subcategories with dozens of real-life examples that made me sit back, think about how I interact with people, and decide to consciously make some changes.In fact, since reading it, I've made an effort to change my reactions/interactions with my kids and all the people I have had to interact with as a result of moving (moving truck drivers, cable installer, lots of customer service reps, etc.). It's been refreshing and enlightening. Not that I was a beast before, but we can all get in the habit of sometimes letting our frustrations get in the way of treating people with the respect and consideration we all deserve. You'll see what I mean when you read the book.

Despite what some reviewers might have you think, this book is not about flattering people with fake platitudes so you can puff up their self-esteem and take advantage of them for personal gain. I've seen a few reviews that state this and it's obvious that they either didn't read the entire book or they only skimmed it. Dale points out multiple times in multiple chapters that the intent of his book isn't to have people flattering others with false praise. If you missed that, it is your fault, not his. As for my review: This is a relatively useful book. Some of the information was common sense to me (don't interrupt people while they're talking), but some of the tidbits were very useful for navigating the workplace as well as "civilian" life. Simple things like making others feel important for their contributions are easily forgotten nowadays, it seems. This book (albeit with the information properly condensed and the examples made age appropriate) would be fantastic for children in younger grades because it teaches you how to listen to others, to respect what they're saying and to expect the same in return. In a perfect world, you would expect parents to teach these types of life skills, but that isn't always the case. I'm sure I'll re-read this book a few times (though I highlighted particularly useful information), but I'm still docking a star because, at least for me, some of the chapters fell flat due to it being common sense to me. But that's just my personal opinion, obviously. You may get more or less use out of it. I suggest you check it out for yourself, though.

'How to Win Friends and Influence People' was the first book recommended to read as part of my Animation degree as so much of our work is done in teams and therefore requires good people relations and the ability to share/sell ideas. For this purpose, I felt that Carnegie did a good job and left me with a lot to ponder on! Carnegie uses lots of anecdotes to help explain and memorize the teachings and the summaries at the end of each section also make the book easier to recap. I'd say the core message in this book is (at the risk of over simplification): treat people kindly and respectfully and they're more likely to listen to what you have to say without adversity. Be humble and patient.

First published in 1937, this still is a classic that surpasses the thousands of other books that have afterwards been published about maintaining successful relations with other people.Although you can feel the 'American Dream' lingering in the background, and even if the fascination of Carnegie for presidents and industrial tycoons feels like an odd choice to a present day reading public, that doesn't take away that the simple principles Carnegie expands are still valid today.Want some basic ones?1) Refrain from complaints or criticism, judge no one2) Show your appreciation, be honest and straightforward3) Instill people with a desire to do or want somethingAs for conversations, the book boils down to: don't be self-centered, stop babbling about yourself and show genuine interest in other people.Carnegie explains all his ideas in a engaging manner and illustrates them with loads of examples or anecdotes.The funniest thing to do with this book is: trying it out!If you apply only a few of the ideas on the people around you, either familiar or new acquaintances, the result is astonishing. Friends visit you more often, total strangers poor their heart out (without being drunk and in a bar) and everybody seems to think you're the nicest person on earth.Thank you for reading this, I really appreciate the time you gave my review. ;-)

I'm not a fan of the title of this book...But, I find that there are many topics within these pages that focus our thoughts, actions, and words on being an encouraging friend and person of influence to the people you are around.  "Being encouraging requires a special attitude. When you look at another person, rather than seeing her faults, you need to be able to see her strengths and possibilities, what she is capable of." "Many of us don't take the time to consider what actually motivates people." p.211 I found this book written to the business audience but I believe teachers, parents, and anyone looking to be a supporting friend can find examples of great moments leaders led others to believe in themselves, something we all should strive to impart in others. :)

This book has been criticized for being a “sycophants-in-training” manual. I happen to agree, but the author tosses in a disclaimer that admonishes readers that his “cracker-barrel idioms” (principles) are not maxims. In fact, the book encourages a trial and error method with his advice and to discard it, if need be. I decided to read this book with a mindset of trying to find some information on how to improve my social interactions with people or to realize when another person is using a manipulative tactic on me. I find this book validated many aspects of social intelligence that I was already aware of, but, none-the-less, there were various anecdotal stories that kept me entertained, whether they were true or not. Here are some takeaways: “Give a person a fine reputation to live up to”. Example: If you are reliant upon a friend’s loyalty, express how you appreciate their loyalty and that you would gamble the house that their loyalty won’t become perfidious. This may or may not cause that person to evaluate how important their pseudo-reputation is before proving themselves to be disloyal, but at least there is potential for a slight advantage of influence to maintain his or her loyalty. When encountering an argument, don’t reverberate back a harsh tone. Most likely, you won’t inspire rationality and open-mindedness when you are deluged in anger. If you have trouble with insubordination amongst your employees, try praising any slight improvements, criticize indirectly, phrase a command within a question (can you do this for me?), lead by example, or invoke a competitive spirit between peer groups. There are many tools the author suggests for this dilemma. Everybody has self-importance. Nobody wants to feel like their life is inconsequential. PRINCIPLE 1: Become genuinely interested in other people. PRINCIPLE 2: SmilePRINCIPLE 3: Remember that a person’s name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language. PRINCIPLE 4: Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves. PRINCIPLE 5: Talk in terms of the other person’s interests. PRINCIPLE 6: Make the other person feel important–and do it sincerely.

It conveys a simple message to win or to attract or to befriend others..Respect them in a gentle and polite manner genuinely, so that you get what you want from them in the same manner. The sad part is everybody is ready to do this to a stranger but not to their kith's and kin's.

This book is a must read.

This is the best self-improvement book I've read. While that's admittedly a small sample size, I have read enough to know that I generally do not like the genre. This, however, was a lot of fun. How to Win Friends and Influence People, by Dale Carnegie, is about how to be a better person in yourself and help other people. As this book talks about a lot of things that the author has encountered in his life, he also talks about the other side of things, and most importantly, how to get what you want. By getting what you want, you also help other people along the way. At the end of the day, you can benefit from your own well being and also help others.The main problem that drives this story is a big problem. This problem is getting what you want. For the author, this was a struggle during his younger years. So he later devised a set of principles that have successfully worked for him and drove him towards the common good. These sets of principles are the resolution to this problem, as it winds down from the confusing maze of human psychology into simple words.This boo was entertaining for multiple reasons. First, the author talks about the mistakes that he made, which later led to not get what he wants. Second, after revealing his mistakes, he later tells us what he did to turn his mistakes around to successfully get what he wants for the benefit of everyone. The only downside to this book is its setting. In order not to spoil you, this book is very amazing and well written.At the end of the day, I would recommend this book to everyone. This book is for people who need a boost in their life and for those who want to improve their relationship in life. It benefits everyone, so take advantage and read this book ASAP!
Very practical methodologies.However, they are mostly surface issues. The book doesn't address the fundamental issues/principles underlying those methodologies.

Good life stradegies.

For people looking to hone their communication skills , this book arguably can be called the Holy Grail.The principles mentioned by Dale Carnegie for effectively dealing with people are spot on and all of them have passed the test of time with flying colors and still hold true today.Most of them are simple and can be translated into real life with little efforts while a few of them demand painstaking efforts to implement.Overall , the book affords an amazing insight into people's behavior.The book is laden with illustrations from Dale Carnegie's life and other great personalities such as Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Andrew Carnegie and so on who have harnessed these principles in their lives successfully. Though these illustrations date back to the early 1900's , they very much resemble the type of situations that people run into in their modern day lives.The ideas are constructed with simple and lucid words enabling us to make the best of each and every one of them.This is not a type of book that you put aside once you read it.If your intentions are to take advantage of the principles mentioned in the book and to be an effective communicator, then this dictates revisiting the concepts in the book every now and then and incessantly practicing them in real life.It puzzles to know that such an incredible book is not incorporated as a text book in our academic education and in modern times I think it is a must-read for everyone.It definitely serves as a perfect guide toward having a sound and healthy professional life as well as an equally good personal life.

I picked this book up at the local library just because I've heard so much about Dale Carnegie. The first few pages of this book tries to sell itself, with the last few pages being a quick reminder that the book was written by a credible author. Finishing the book left me with an impression of the book being a marketing product rather than a work of art.Content wise, the book does exactly what it says on the cover - it teaches you how to win people over (no surprise there). The book was first written in 1937 and has since been altered to suit with the change in time. With that said, I wouldn't take anything away from this book other than the concept of being tactful and patient in dealing with people in every circumstance.The author gives examples of tactics that Lincoln and himself have used when in tricky 'real-life' situations, while also noting that these methods used do not guarantee success as situations and individuals may vary with each case...(thank you for the disclaimer, I guess?)This book gave many quick-fixes on how to get along in an environment of different personalities and how to not make life any harder for yourself (and others for that matter) than it already is, albeit provided little insight into bringing a more permanent solution in dealing with difficult people.I guess I'm a little disappointed after reading this book as it came off as selfishly cunning more than empathetic. Definitely a good book to read to remind yourself that there is always a better way to deal with your emotions to avoid bringing about your own downfall, but not something to make a mantra of.Giving this 4 stars because although a little shallow, stuff in this book makes you think a little :)
Probably the best of the self-improvement books. Uplifting and positive.

This is an easy, pleasant read affirming the golden rule in dealing with others. Such a classic that it's a clique (in the US, at least). I referred to it in another review so I should point out that I have read it and thought it actually gives very timely advice.

What was most interesting about this book for me was that it was published more than 80 years ago but it's as timely now as it was then. The psychological concepts of interpersonal relationships are so well explained and presented with interesting narrative examples of the concepts in action.In the last 20 years or so we've become such a "Me, me, me!!" society that this book reminds us of how to be better people, better friends, better employers, better employees. Given the state of the job market today we need all the help we can get too.What isn't mentioned, at least not in the edition I read, is the connection between the principles discussed and spirituality. Today there is a greater trend towards increasing our awareness of those outside ourselves and putting others first. This is the crux of Carnegie's method.Much of what he outlines is basic common sense and decency in dealing with others that we forget all about when we are after fulfilling our own needs as quickly as possible. We completely forget, if we have even ever realized, that attending to others' interests furthers our own as well.
The negative reviews for this book are hilarious.

The book is full of extremely practical advise on how you can improve on all aspects of your social interactions both privately and in business. The premise of the book is not about manipulating others, but instead showing how you yourself can become a better (social) person by following simple rules. I truly believe that taking the discussed points in the book into practice will positively change your life and I'm already actively applying some of this newly found wisdom. A minor point of critique is that a lot of anecdotes are being described in the book and not all of them are that interesting, which is probably in part due to the time in which the book was written (almost a century ago). Also quite some points seem to overlap a lot and repetition of all sort is spread throughout the book (which also helps hitting the points home).

Dale Breckenridge Carnegie adalah seorang penulis Amerika dan dosen dan pengembang kursus yang terkenal dalam pengembangan diri, keahlian menjual, pelatihan perusahaan, berbicara di depan umum dan interpersonal.Segala nasihat dan panduan yang terkandung dalam buku ini berjaya mengubah nasib kebanyakan golongan yang terkenal di dunia terutama sekali dalam kehidupan profesional dan peribadi mereka.Dalam Edisi bagaimana Memenangi Hati Kawan dan Mempengaruhi Orang Lain yang dikemas kini ini pasti dapat membantu mengasah bakat kita yang terpendam. Dengan membaca buku ini, kita mampu mencapai tahap potensi yang maksimum.Dalami tip berikut:- Tiga teknik asas dalam menangani kelakuan manusia- Enam kaedah bagaimana membuatkan orang menyukai kita- Dua belas cara bagi mendorong orang lain menerima buah fikiran kita- Sembilan taktik bagi mengubah manusia tanpa mencetuskan konflikSerta banyak lagi!

Getwijfeld tussen drie en vier sterren, wegens hier en daar toch wat verouderd of al te simplistisch voorgesteld. Los daarvan: wel behoorlijk wat boeiende inzichten in de menselijke psyche, dus wel graag gelezen.

Excellent book. The principles are priceless and have stood the test of time. While technology has affected how some things are executed, there is no question to the value of the personal connections and considerations promoted by Dale Carnegie

I read this book a few years back and I really liked it. At the same time I couldn't really decide on if it's ok or not to "fake" your personality in a way that makes people like you more. Dale writes that you should be sincere about the personality changes that is proposed in the book but it sometimes feels more like something that is added so the changed behaviour would stand out to be too manipulative.I wasn't able to put my finger on what it was that felt wrong with this book until I read Stephen R. Coveys book "The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People: Powerful Lessons in Personal Change" a month ago.In the beginning of this book Covey divides personal development books into two cathegories. Books focusing on character ethics and books focusing on personality ethics. This division along with the fact that I had already read the book he refers to when he refers to character ethics (The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin) made it all make sense to me.How to win friends and influence people is a personal development book that focuses on personality ethics. It does not however focus on how to build the character that is needed to live up to these ethics in a sincere way.If you make the personality changes according to these books without having the character behind it to make them sincere you risk that people will judge you as manipulative and that they get this feeling about you that you many times get about sales people that they don't really want what's in your best interest.I really recommend reading all three of these books however and see if you see the same connections that I see.

This book spoke to me. It's a veritable primer on human interaction. But the danger with this kind of work is that it's possible to reduce these interactions to mere supeficial techniques and lose sight of the substance.

After reading this book, I realized why I don't have many friends. I realized all these bad things that I do subconsciously that repel people. I can't just expect people to be my friend if I don't put myself out there. Here are some lessons I learned from this book : don't complain or criticize, appreciate, make people feel important and focus on their interests, listen more than you talk, don't argue, see things from their perspective, and more. I know I should apply these lessons to life, but it feels hard. I need to get brave enough and confident enough to. I don't know. Well now I know how to get along with people but it's easier said than done.

So to win friends, I have to stop critizing directly and start praising people's real accomplishments? Talking about 180° turns, how to get rid of these "friends", after being so nice to them?You know, once I hit my personal Dunbar's number of about a dozen, less friends are better...But to be fair and objective and everything:The part about influencing people broadened my horizon.Thanks Dale! I'll try emulating your attitude and see what happens.

Interesting read. Carnegie provides plenty of anecdotal evidence for his claims. You will basically get the picture after a few chapters in. The first thing that came into my mind after finishing the book is why I didn’t read it any earlier! I wish I had read it (10) years ago, but thank God it’s never too late.Well, this book is very important for those who must handle their relationships with care and need to get their desires fulfilled while dealing with others.What I liked about the book’s content is that doesn’t promote a manipulative type of character to its readers. This is a brief summary of the book.Techniques for handling people:Don't criticize or complainShow honest appreciation Arose an eager want in the other people6 Principles for making people like you:1/ Be genuinely interested in other people.2/ Smile.3/ Remember the other person's name and how it holds great influence.4/ Be a good listener and encourage others to talk about themselves.5/ Talk in terms of other person's interest.6/ Make the other person feel important -and do it sincerely.Note:Always avoid an acute angel. Arguments are to be avoided as much as possible. 12 Principles for how to win people to your way of thinking:1- Avoid arguments.2- Respect others' opinions: never say, "You are wrong."3- If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.4- Begin in a friendly way.5- Get the other person saying "Yes, yes." immediately.6- Let the other person do a great deal of the talking.7- Let the other person feel that the idea is his/hers.8- Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view.9- Be sympathetic with other person's ideas and desires.10- Appeal to the nobler motives.11- Dramatize your ideas.12- Throw down a challenge.The effective leader should keep the following guidelines in mind to change attitude:1- Be sincere: don't promise anything you can't deliver. (Concentrate on the benefits the other person going to have.)2- Know exactly what it is you want the other person to do.3- Be emphatic (Ask yourself what is the other person really wants.)4- Consider the benefits the other person will receive from doing what you suggest.5- Match those benefits to the other person's wants.6- When you make your request, put it in a form that will convey to the other person the idea that he personally will benefit.9 Principles for how to be a leader who has the ability to change people without giving offense or arousing resentment:1. Begin with praise and honest appreciation.2. Call attention to people’s mistakes indirectly.3. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.4. Ask questions instead of giving direct orders.5. Let the other person save face.6. Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement. Be “hearty in your approbation and lavish in your praise.”7. Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to.8. Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct.9. Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest.

asked one word to describe How to win friends and influence people, I will definitely choose "inspiring". While some of the same kind only list out the "Do" and "Don't" things,this book briefly demonstrate the ideas through various examples and stories. I did not have to try much to remember the theories and instead had the chance to analyze and understand them in my own ways. Sometime I got confused when some ideas are repeated throughout the books, some more than twice, as if the writer really wanted to emphasize them in the reader's minds. Maybe to me the book doesn't word out the way it ought to, because the greatest thing I learn from this book is not how to influence people but that it does not take much time and effort to show our beloved ones that we truly care for them. Although this idea is written in this book as a fundamental rule in communicating and influencing people, just as the book is meant to teach people to behave in a way so that others will love and corporate with them, I realize that while practicing this, I am the first to feel happy and satisfied. I do not intend to influence anyone or to win their love, I just know through the stories in the that there're are great many ways to show our affections and feelings for others, and that it takes time to develop the HABIT of caring for their problems instead of ours. While reading the Second Chapter, I felt the urge to stand up and call my sister who has been in the hospital the whole week taking after my grandad, to text another sister who is working hard at her office, to send my friends and teachers e-cards at the Valentine and to think positively about the recently problems in my family. I don't know if I will be able to have impacts on anyone, but this book has inspired me live more selflessly, and as Gandhi once said: be the change you want to see in the world, may this be a good sign?

At worst this is a collection of charming anecdotes about people being nice to each other with the word "salesman" scattered randomly about. At best it is a life-changing guide for social interaction and understanding. For me, it is admittedly closer to the latter and I'm completely and happily surprised by that. The title is totally misleading, and while it does have a mind for business, this book precedes the cynicism of the self help era and names its heroes as historical figures who always asked their butler how Barbara, his mother, was fairing. The author, Carnegie, calls us (and himself) out repeatedly as simple creatures who just want a little appreciation and have a lot of pride, and reminds that everyone else is just the same. Pay a complement, remember a name, let the other person talk his heart out, let him save face, and here's a meandering story about Lincoln and letter-writing to illustrate the point. My favorite aspect, and the attitude that really structures the philosophy, is the rule that a person should strive to (although there is no assumption that this is difficult in practice) develop a genuine interest in others. There is an inherent belief in humanity and the idea that reader has plenty to gain from learning about others. Charming, optimistic, engaging. Good read to start off a new year.

Oh if only the principals in this book were widely practiced, this would would be a happier place! What I loved about this book is that it does not have the typical icky self-help book feel. Its instead Dale exhorting us to show genuine interest in others, respect them, really listen, make their interest your own interest. Seek to see things from their point of view, give genuine affirmation and praise, never criticize or argue, believe the best about them, humble yourself and be quick to confess your faults, etc... I suppose it can all be summed up in "Love your neighbor as yourself" and also the scripture "If you seek to find your life, you'll lose it, but if you lose your life for my sake, you'll find it" comes to mind, for the way to find life, is to not seek it, but to give yourself away. As Jesus said, "If you want to become first, you must become a servant to all". though this is not a religious book, I just feel Carnegie does an amazing job of showing how its really in our own best interest to deny ourselves and prefer others before ourselves. I absolutely loved this book.

When the great Peter Malherbe, newsman to the bone, left his positon at the Sunday Times, he handed me this book. His words, knowing that journalists are somewhat cynical of this sort of business mumbo-jumbo, were something along the lines of "Read it. It's actually very useful". I did and it was.The book's core message is that you can force people to do things, you can exercise power over them to bend them to your will, but if you really want the best out of them, you need to find out what it is that drives them and match that drive to your objectives. In short, you must understand what it is that they want. And, in many instances, the desire isn't for money. It's for recognition, being listened to, and being acknowledged. Once you take that approach, it's amazing how the doors open, the atmosphere lightens and things get done.Did it change my life? Not really. Did it change the way I see people in the workplace? Absolutely.

And, so far, that has been working tremendously well for me. Therefore, I think I've earned invaluable insights from this book. It'a always good to revisit old books. The forgetfulness of my memory is quite astonishing. Okay. I'm going off-tangent. 4/5 it is.

Why do people hate this book, right off the bat? Because nobody likes to think that someone else could use a formula to trick you into being friends with or influenced by that person. The problem with this book is that it is structured in a way that implies each principle can work independently of the others. It's unfortunate that Dale Carnegie made this mistake while organizing the book- he even goes so far as to give examples in each section of the principles working "independently" that sometimes sound extremely unrealistic. Almost all of the principles he provides are excellent ideas but the most important thing (and this is something I think Carnegie should have stressed in every chapter and not just the first and last) is obviously sincerity. Don't bullshit people. Say what you came to say. That PROVIDED- being a good listener can take you a long way. Many of Carnegies ideas are RE-active suggestions- you can't just trot into someone's office and ask a person what his or her hobbies are. Get to the point.If you're willing to do a little bit of the work for the author and put 2 and 2 together- The principles work as a group of ideas rather than independently- then you will gain a lot from this book. Since reading it and being in scenarios where there was explicit or implicit haggling involved (let's face it- most of life is some form of bargaining) I've found these tools to be 10000% relevant. And have definitely gained from them. I highly recommend this book for people who would like to have more friends and influence by means of sincerity. I don't UN-recommend this for the insincere, I just know that no matter how hard they may try to manipulate their peers, it'll eventually come back to bite them in the ass.------review after having read a few chapters------Despite the voice of an author reaching into 2010 from almost 100 years ago, I'm finding this book to be incredibly apt and frankly just darling in tone. The author has an earnest and affable voice that makes me happy to pick the book back up. Each chapter offers advice that I can apply immediately and from which I consistently find immediate satisfaction. The author hazards against insincerity or artificiality in applying his suggestions, making this book 100% genuine. I'm not half way through but I can already tell this will be a favorite.

Audiobook.I wanted to give this book 3 stars: "WHAT? Only 3 stars for this gem? How can you…?" is what I hear you saying. Yes, I, too, had very high hopes for this book. And I liked it. That's what 3 stars mean, I liked it. To rate it higher, there were a couple of things missing:- Fewer examples: Carnegie is really giving a lot of examples, up to a point where I'd say: "Enough. I get it. Please, no more…"- More science: I agree with most of his points, however, he's not backing most of them up with science. There's a few references to B.F. Skinner's behavioral theories, but not much more.- Clearer advice: maybe because the lack of scientific reference in the book, I find a few of his principles questionable. Part 3, "12. Throw down a challenge." is not what I want other people do to me (I can do that fine by myself, thank you); Part 4, "2. Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly." is what I usually try to avoid, since I value open and direct communication; Part 4, "3. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person." seems to me like what I know as "sandwich feedback", i.e. giving negative feedback between giving positive feedback at the beginning and at the end of a conversation. Carnegie addresses this problem with principle 4.3 though, which he sees in not giving _sincere_ positive feedback. But then again, I might have only received insincere positive feedback when receiving sandwich feedback.Other than that, I really liked the book. If it were a tad smaller (fewer examples), it's a really good summary of behaviours to hold dear in life. All the other principles in this book are, from my experience and point of view, very much something to strive for when developing oneself. 4 stars it is.The principles discussed in this book are (via http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_to_W... ):Part: Fundamental Techniques in Handling People1. Don't criticize, condemn, or complain.2. Give honest and sincere appreciation.3. Arouse in the other person an eager want.Part: Six Ways to Make People Like You1. Become genuinely interested in other people.2. Smile.3. Remember that a person's name is, to that person, the sweetest and most important sound in any language.4. Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves.5. Talk in terms of the other person's interest.6. Make the other person feel important – and do it sincerely.Part: Twelve Ways to Win People to Your Way of Thinking1. The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.2. Show respect for the other person's opinions. Never say "You're Wrong."3. If you're wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.4. Begin in a friendly way.5. Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view.9. Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires.10. Appeal to the nobler motives.11. Dramatize your ideas.12. Throw down a challenge.Part: Be a Leader: How to Change People Without Giving Offense or Arousing Resentment1. Begin with praise and honest appreciation.2. Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly.3. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.4. Ask questions instead of giving direct orders.5. Let the other person save face.6. Praise every improvement.7. Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to.8. Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct.9. Make the other person happy about doing what you suggest.
Really, this books makes us to win, if we follow the mentioned items in correct way as it depicts. I even followed one technique and win a situation. If am, why not you win the people?

Manusia diciptakan berbeda satu sama lain. Itu membuat manusia menjadi makhluk yang rumit sekaligus mudah dipahami. Walaupun diciptakan dengan watak dan perilaku yang berbeda, tetapi ada satu hal mendasar yang pasti dimiliki oleh semua manusia. Yakni sifat manusia untuk ingin selalu dianggap sebagai orang yang penting. Simpelnya, semua orang ingin dihargai. Nasihat dari buku ini secara keseluruhan yakni "perlakukan orang lain sebagaimana kamu ingin diperlakukan". Menurut saya semua nasihat-nasihat di buku ini sangat masuk akal dan bermanfaat sekali. Buku ini banyak memberikan contoh nyata dari orang-orang yang sudah mempraktekan nasihat dari penulis, sehingga membuat buku ini kelihatan tebal. Tetapi sebenarnya dengan membaca tiap akhir bab sudah bisa didapat kesimpulannya yang hanya beberapa poin penting saja. Saya sarankan teman-teman membaca buku ini, coba praktekan, dan lihat apa yang terjadi (ala Mario Teguh). Itung-itung buat investasi di masa depan ketika nanti sudah terjun ke masyarakat. Worth to read.

First published in 1936, this is a classic American self-help book. Despite being a product of its time, I think most of the ideas continue to be relevant. It discusses the following principles:Handling people: (1) Don't criticize, condemn or complain; (2) Give honest and sincere appreciation; (3) Try to make the other person understand why the other person would actually want to do the thing you think they should do. To make people like you: (1) Become genuinely interested in other people; (2) Smile; (3) Remember the other person's name and use it; (4) Be a good listener, and encourage others to talk about themselves; (5) Talk in terms of the other person's interests; (6) Make the other person feel important-and do it sincerely. Win People To Your Way Of Thinking: (1) Avoid arguments; (2) Respect the other person's opinions, and never say, "You're wrong"; (3) If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically; (4) Begin in a friendly way; (5) Get the other person saying "yes, yes" immediately; (6) Let the other person do a great deal of the talking; (7) Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers; (8) Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view; (9) Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires; (10) Appeal to the nobler motives; (11) Dramatize your ideas; (12) Throw down a challenge. Being a leader (changing your people's attitudes and behavior): (1) Begin with praise and honest appreciation; (2) Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly; (3) Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person; (4) Ask questions instead of giving direct orders; (5) Let the other person save face; (6) Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement; (7) Be "hearty in your approbation and lavish in your praise"; (7) Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to; (8) Use encouragement, and make the fault seem easy to correct; (9) Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest. Making Your Home Life Happier: (1) Don't nag; (2) Don't try to make your partner over; (3) Don't criticize; (3) Give honest appreciation; (4) Pay little attentions; (6) Be courteous; (7) Read a good book on the sexual side of marriage.This all seems like good advice. But it's hard to put in practice, and it's hard to do all of this stuff sincerely. It basically doesn't work if you're being phony. This book points out that you need to genuinely appreciate other people; you can't just flatter them.These kinds of books make me think about a couple of core concepts we're all taught and what they really mean. The first is in this book. The author points out "probably the most important rule in the world: Do unto others as you would have others do unto you." I think that's obviously true in a very general sense: give others what they want, just as you would want others to give you what you want. But it's untrue that you should literally do unto others as you would have others do unto you, because others are different from you. You should do unto others as others would have you do unto them. There are only a small minority of people who are similar to me and want the same things I want. I need to figure out what other people want and give that to them; not give them what I would want.The second is "Thou shalt not lie." I'm very literal, so telling people what they want to hear, and not telling people what I'm really thinking seems like lying to me. I know that most people don't think of "white lies" as being lies at all; they just think of them as an expression of kindness. For me, one thing that is difficult about applying the principles of a book like this is to remember that for most people, in a lot of situations, the literal words that come out of someone's mouth are irrelevant; they actually "don't count" as even being part of the communication. The actual communication is in the person's body language and tone of voice. I think of lot winning friends and influencing people comes down to telling what people consider to be socially appropriate white lies, and telling them with convincing body language and tone of voice. Ideally, this can be pulled off without actually lying; rather than saying the hurtful thing you are really thinking, you say something different that is actually true. At times, I think this requires an almost zen-like detachment from one's own feelings and emotions; to get what you want, never express what you actually want or feel. I think that no matter how many books a person reads, it's hard for a person who is actually not compassionate to come across as being compassionate.

Part One: Fundamental Techniques in Handling PeopleDon’t criticize, condemn, or complain. (It rarely helps the situation)Give honest sincere appreciation.Arouse in the other person an eager want.Part Two: Six Ways To Make People Like YouBecome genuinely interested in other people.Smile.Remember that a person’s name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language.Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves. (This is the secret to being a great conversationalist.)Talk in terms of the other person’s interests.Make the other person feel important—and do it sincerely.Part Three: Win People To Your Way Of ThinkingThe only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it. (Because even if you win, you aren’t going to get what you want.)Show respect for the other person’s opinions. Never say, “You’re wrong.”If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically. (A good way to start is to admit that you could be mistaken.)Begin in a friendly way.Get the other person saying “yes, yes” immediately.Let the other person do a great deal of the talking.Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers.Try honestly to see things from the other person’s point of view.Be sympathetic with the other person’s ideas and desires.Appeal to the nobler motives. (Even if deep down they make the decision based on the baser ones. Everyone wants to be the hero of their own story.)Dramatize your ideas. (A picture and a story are worth a thousand words.)Throw down a challenge. (Do this when all else fails.) Part Four: Be A Leader: How To Change People Without Giving Offense Or Arousing ResentmentBegin with praise and honest appreciation.Call attention to people’s mistakes indirectly.Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.Ask questions instead of giving direct orders.Let the other person save face.Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement. Be “hearty in your approbation and lavish in your praise.”Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to.Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct.Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest.
Great ideas to keep in mind when working with others

Great book - but the ONLY section that would NOT work for corporate America today is "If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically." Working for corporate - everyone knows if you take responsibility for a blow up, it's a mark on your record and you can get fired for it. That's something I learned from my boss - make sure you know how to play the game - make sure you cover your bases so that you don't get blamed for anything because the second you do, it can cost you that promotion or even your job.Amazing book, the only problem is that the other party must be human to reciprocate and understand your intentions, nowadays in corporations it's difficult to be treated as human being and expect corporate to treat you like one, but following these steps will definitely help.Sometimes the book seems naive at heart compared to how the world has changed today & how it interacts (corporations, internet, etc.), but overall the same principles apply.Other sections were very interesting in the sense that they were very manipulative - you have to understand this book was written to help navigate politics of the workplace, but whether you use these techniques for altruistic reasons are completely up to you. Some of the anecdotes about Charles Schwab, Andrew Carnegie, and others were very interesting in the sense that they were terrible people who settled disputes through manipulation using these techniques. Again Carnegie never claimed to be a moral or ethical person, he wrote this book so that you can SEEM more pleasant and ethical in the workplace. ;)For most readers this fact is lost on them, and people use these techniques in positive ways for good reasons, and even Carnegie insists of using empathy to connect with others. If you use these techniques for good that's all that matters! Definitely apply to your everyday, I think this book should be read by everyone, every single person on the planet! That's how good it is!

I read this book a few years ago as part of a Dale Carnegie leadership training program I attended for my job at the time. I was moving into more of a managerial role and my boss was into these kinds of interpersonal skill building exercises. This is the same course where they teach you to use word association to remember people’s names. The only name I remember now was this hot girl Meghan Ardnt because I figured I “aren’t makin’” any headway with this one once I found out she was married. The format of the course forced us to try out the tools laid out in the book because we would have to give a five minute speech about how we used a particular skill that was discussed the previous week and what the results were. All about stepping out of our comfort zone. One dude stormed out circa week 9 never to be seen again. I think his name was Stormy.The book is about techniques you can use if you’re managing anyone, if you’re working as part of a team, if you’re in sales, or even if you’re in “sales”. The same techniques are just as applicable in everyday life as well. Some examples: Use a person’s name when talking to them; it’s the most important sound in any language. It works! How many people do that? I can count the number I know personally on one hand. It gets attention and makes them feel important.Let the other person feel that the idea is his own. It works! Try leading somebody down the path to what you want them to do instead of outright telling them what to do. Ask question you know the answer to. Nobody likes taking orders, everybody likes to think they are in control. Trickster.Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct. It works! Kinda! Praise for the slightest improvement seems to keep hope up for people but sometimes it’s hard to put a positive spin on the situation after say the second or third job you lost because of your serious drinking problem.I highly recommend this book. While it is easy enough to find the principles listed out online, the book gives real life examples from Dale and his students’ lives. His enthusiasm makes you want to run out and try them right away. Even if you don’t have an opportunity to try them all if you pick out two or three to use, you’ll see positive results. Sometimes it’s fun just to see how far you can manipulate people using as many principles as possible in one situation. Good at parties…try it!

I have a friend who thinks this is phony bologna. On the other hand, I see it as a really worthwhile read. Whatever the difference, perhaps I was much more lacking in my networking skills and interpersonal relationship savvy. Maybe I just have the ability to get the good out of a wider variety of sources. Who knows!? I loved reading the many personal stories that Mr. Carnegie used to explain the points he makes about successful ways of being for greatest benefit to relationships. I come into this reading with the interest to communicate more effectively the love and appreciation I have for those around me. If I were reading it as part of a marketing class, I would indeed feel phony. I think Dale Carnegie has a lot of wonderful personal insights and I appreciate very much having read this book.

This book is a self-help book for teenage girls, and this is the 2nd self-help book I've read this year. Basically, Donna Dale Carnegie wrote this book to help teenage girls learn how to make friends. The author is trying to say, and is saying, what we need to work on in order to be positively influential to other people (as a "sister, daughter, friend, and girlfriend" as she says). You can call this an exposition considering how the author analyzes how we, as teenage girls, handle ourselfs in certain situations. She gives genuine steps to being a positive, friendly, and social, role model. I like this book, I wouldn't change a thing about it. I needed a book like this because I don't have any friends, and I never really did because of how antisocial I am. I tried to make friends during this year but I didn't feel like It was going anywhere, so I quit. I think that I should give this a 2nd chance now that I've read this book and there is nothing that I don't like about the book. It's not similar to a book that I've read before besides "Your Medical Mind" considering these are both self-help books, but maybe that's beccause I don't read that much. I'd recommend this book to teenage girls everywhere who need help making friends.

Encourage others to talk about themselves.-Talk in terms of the other person’s interests.-Make the other person feel important – and do it sincerely.Win people to your way of thinking:-The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.-Show respect for the other person’s opinions. How to Win Friends and Influence People is informative and entertaining, and just as useful today as it was when it was first published in 1937. This is the case because Dale Carnegie had an understanding of human nature that will never be outdated. Carnegie explains that you can make a friend out of just about anyone and get them to do what you want them to, without arousing resentment, by seeing the situation from that person's point of view. He suggests that you can do this in a number of ways such as by appealing to the other person's highest ideals, remembering their name, letting them do most of the talking and speaking in terms of their interests. For instance, "let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers," and "talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person." Carnegie illustrates his points with anecdotes of historical figures, leaders of the business world, and everyday folks. Financial success, Carnegie explains is due 15 percent to professional knowledge and 85 percent to "the ability to express ideas, to assume leadership, and to arouse enthusiasm among people." He teaches these skills through underlying principles of dealing with people so that they feel important and appreciated. If there is one thing you learn from the book, it is the ability to understand the different views of other people in different situations. He begins the book with the foundations of developing this skill of understanding others. He extends three principles that if applied will help you identify what other people want and how you can satisfy them. After that he introduces six ways to make people like you. These methods hover around the same three principles mentioned in the beginning of the book. After that the author discusses in two parts methods and principles that help you influence people to your way of thinking. The advice in the book is largely sound, but it’s important to remember that the book was initially intended as a companion book to his classes on how to be a good salesman. In other words, these techniques work very well in relationships that are not expected to be long-lasting so may not be ideal for all your close personal relationships. Similarly these techniques won’t work on all people as there are some people with whom it is impossible to get along.

I have read a few of these 'help/informative' books and this classic by Dale Carnegie has been the best one in my eyes. He uses multiple examples of everything including not only work place examples but everyday at home ones so all types of readers can really relate.

There are many important lessons in Dale Carnegie’s How to Win Friends and Influence People, but one major message on handling difficult situations or people is to not criticize, condemn, or complain. Criticism is futile because it puts a person on the defensive and usually makes him strive to justify himself. In a study done by the world famous psychologist B.F. Skinner, it was proven that an animal “rewarded for good behavior” would learn much more rapidly and effectively than an animal being “punished for bad behavior” (6). This shows that criticism only hinders the problem, whereas, appreciation for good behavior will solve the problem and others as well. The person being corrected or condemned will only retaliate with criticism and condemnation and try to justify him or herself instead of focusing on what actually needs correction. A simile that stuck out that applies to this claim is “criticisms are like homing pigeons, they always return home”, meaning that giving criticisms only end in receiving criticisms, so it is important to “breed sympathy, tolerance, and kindness” (8,18). Through psychological experiments and personal experiences, it is inferable that criticisms and condemnations only seem to cause backtracking from the original intention.

I am not a big fan of self-help books. But I found this one interesting. It is not amoral and didactic (like 48 Rules of Power). It suggests practical common sense ways on how to deal with people with integrity and honesty, yet get along with them well to ensure that your work gets done. It's one of those books that are "bestsellers" AND contain useful information too! P.S. - It's less of "How to win Friends" and more of "How to Influence People". No book can teach you how to win friends. You simply can't "win" friends!
The amazing ideas of you can make your charisma to be felt by others.
Would have been 5 stars but for the fact that the methods therein are probably less applicable to today's generations.
Be like Abe Lincoln and don't critisize! I don't agree w/ all the authors points but this is a provocative read that every person should try on for size!
Originally read this book my freshmen year of college and read it as a refresher - still a great read. The information is still applicable in the 21st century.

CRnegie's classic is one of my favourites. This third time through the book was also my most enjoyable. I have found it more challenging to put many of these principles into practice, but also a greater sense of accomplishment when doing so. Maybe I've become more honest with myself. I pledge to read this book and follow its principles at least every other year. I find his stories and anecdotes entertaining and helpful in illustrating his points, and his knowledge of a great many historical figures is worth the price of admission itself!

Maar een stel inzichten werkt natuurlijk nog altijd erg goed. Vaak getest in werkomgevingen en zeer plezierig om te gebruiken.
