I have mixed thoughts about this book, I guess. Most of the techniques are blindingly obvious, common sense things that people don't need to read this book to know. How do you make friends? Constantly praise people and always be interested in what they are saying! (There is a whole chapter on each)A few of the others are cheap salesman tricks that everyone already uses. How do you make your customers feel important? Talk about their desires and constantly call people by name! (A "sales pitch" usually means a lengthy explanation of why people will benefit from buying the product, and salesmen are always calling customers by their names. The first technique is so overused that it is expected, and as soon as the sales pitch begins, the customer begins the task of poking holes in your presentation. The second technique is just downright creepy. When people ask my name at a coffee shop or a fast-food restaurant, I'm always tempted to say: "None of your business! I'm just a guy standing in line to buy something; don't pretend I mean more than that!") A few of his ideas are both cheap salesman tricks AND blindingly obvious common sense suggestions. (Smile!) So part of me wants to say that this book doesn't have any original ideas.A couple of problems with saying that, though. This book was written in 1936 and has had enormous influence on the business world. His techniques may seem like "cheap salesman tricks" at this point because salespeople all over the world have employed them, finding them incredibly successful. Salesmen use "cheap tricks" because they work. Also, Dale Carnegie never says that his ideas are new or original. The bulk of each chapter consists of multiple examples of how successful people have been using the described technique since time began. These success stories concern world leaders such as Lincoln, Teddy Roosevelt, And Winston Churchill. They also involve high-profile business leaders such as Andrew Carnegie, Rockefeller, Charles Schwab, and others, famous people from Charles Dickens to Ben Franklin to Queen Victoria, and a wide variety or ordinary "common folks" stories. (Most of this last category are student of Carnegie courses, and it's hardly surprises that their teacher would have great things to say about their success. Particularly when that same teacher is advising the principle: "Be lavish in your appreciation and hearty in your praise." ) Carnegie is not so much inventing new ideas as combining ideas that work into a volume, and he tells you that. Such a tactic today would be a cheap salesman trick; his book was the first of it's kind. It definitely started something, but is it a good thing?I have no answer to that now. First, I read a library copy of the book. This meant I was forbidden to do what the book suggests: highlight key passages, write notes in the margins, and fill the back pages with your own remarks. I found several places where I would have liked to do that. This review is a "first read" and this book is not meant to be read only once. The treatment Dale Carnegie recommends seems a little creepy: that you review your notes and the chapters on a regular basis, that you constantly dwell on your experience with the techniques, that you always consider how to live better through them. Seems kind of like the devout Christian's relationship to scripture. I wonder what the reaction in the religious community was back in 1936, or if the if the "nine suggestions to get the most out of this book" were added later. More importantly, the test of this book is really applying its lessons to the world of business, an experiment I'll be seeing in action soon. So I give this book a tentative 4 star rating for now, for shear power and influence. How to Win Friends and Influence People indeed. This book has succeeded in both. It has a huge fan base, and has been widely followed. The fans are the friends the book has won, and the following is the influence it has had on people. Remarkable.After the upcoming test, I may change my rating and give an explanation. This review may have to be modified.

I read this book during the Taliban regime (1999) when the TV, Radio and everything was banned. I rented the Persian version of this book from our local shopkeeper. The title was translated "How to make friends". It was an interesting book for a 15 years me.I recommend this book for people to learn how to interact with people and approach them. It is a good book overall.

This is definitely the kind of book that you need to read several times in order to fully reap its benefits. The message of the book is timeless although it was written nearly 80 years ago. He stresses the importance of sincerity and honesty as opposed to flattery which I think really sets this book apart. Some of the anecdotes used as examples were a bit dated and boring, which was to be expected. Overall, this book is a classic that everyone should read in order to better learn how to effectively deal with people.
interesting

I read this book from a Vietnamese version after hearing people mention and recommend it for years. It is a great book with all valuable advices and lessons, true. Only appearing in my thoughts while reading it, those stories may be changed in some ways to fit into new society. Of course, the core messages will remain with their full meanings but their application should be taken with the consideration of current changing world and life. It is just simply like prior to being a good person to help and care for others, that person should take good care of him/herself.Anyway, it would be an excellent book to read not only once in a lifetime but as many as you wish and whenever you want to find an inner peace and calm.
Great book about common social practices.

Despite of the title induces a thinking of self-help book, this book is precursor of the negotiation book Getting the Yes and lots of techniques of leadership.All lessons of the book are focused on how to deal with people, even in unpleasant situations. The influence lessons are always directed in how I should treat people. The author give feasible lessons how to be truly empathetic with other person's situation and how to motivate always. The book often repeats the lessons over and over the chapters and contains lots of cases about the people who did Carnigie's course. Some of them make the lesson clear others are just to sell his course.I strong recommend this book for new leaders and who frequently deals with people and teams.

Say things In terms of what's important to your audience. Get them saying yes before you make the ask. Take a genuine interest in others. People like to talk about themselves. They really don't care about you or what you want to say. Just a few of the lessons learned from this book. Lots of good examples to clarify each principal.
insightful book

This is one of my favorite books in the self-help genre I've read for a while. I know of other books that I've read that suggest Carnegie's approach is too simplistic, but I am with him all the way. Loved it!

Classic self-help book. It has genuine tips, unlike most modern self-help books. In summary,Fundamental techniques in handling people 1. Don't criticize, condemn or complain. 2. Give honest and sincere appreciation. 3. Arouse in the other person an eager wantSix ways to make people like you 1. Become genuinely interested in other people. 2. Smile 3. Remember that a person's name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language. 4. Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves. 5. Talk in terms of the other person's interests. 6. Make the other person feel important - and do it sincerely.Win people to your way of thinking 1. The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it. 2. Show respect for the other person's opinions. Never say, "You're wrong." 3. If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically. 4. Begin in a friendly way. 5. Get the other person saying "yes, yes" immediately. 6. Let the other person do a great deal of the talking. 7. Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers. 8. Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view. 9. Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires. 10. Appeal to the nobler motives. 11. Dramatize your ideas. 12. Throw down a challenge.Be a leader 1. Begin with praise and honest appreciation. 2. Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly. 3. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person. 4. Ask questions instead of giving direct orders. 5. Let the other person save face. 6. Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement. 7. Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to. 8. Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct. 9. Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest.

I read this book when I was in high school, and like so many people, it had a huge influence on my life. The two main things I learned from it were to take the time to look at any situation from the perspective of the other person, and that it is possible to get people to follow your lead while still acting morally and ethically. Although virtually everything else in the world may be spinning out of control, human nature does not and has not changed. Manifestations may change, but human nature itself stays the same. For that reason, I can still recommend this book as a tool for becoming better acquainted with the psychological predilections within oneself and others.

This is an interesting read, that supports a very positve philosophy in dealing with people, and gives numerous success stories. There is no doubt however, that the book is dated in a less cynical time. The weight of the examples also apply more towards a person struggling to maintain a leadership position rather than obtain a position of influence. All in all, I do recommend this book, at the very least, it is uplifting, easy to read, and will make its reader more willing to empathize with other people.

Even though the book is dated the concepts of human emotions would never change. Dale Carnegie highlights the principles that are required to get along with people. He very clearly mentions that all the principles in the book will work only if its followed with sincerity and genuinity. Thanks Natalie for recommending it, its indeed a good read.
A classic read about how to spread your ideas without turning people off.

หนังสือเล่มนี้เป็นหนังสือที่ดังมากช่วงสามสิบถึงห้าสิบปีก่อน เคยได้ยินชื่อหนังสือกับผู้เขียนมานานแล้ว เพิ่งเห็นเล่มแปลก็เลยลองซื้อมาอ่านค่ะ เป็นหลักการที่ดีมาก ในการพูดจา ซึ่งก็คือการเอาใจเขามาใส่ใจเรา หลักการยิ้มแย้ม เอาใจใส่คนที่เราพูดด้วย ซึ่งเรียบเรียงเป็นหัวข้อไว้อย่างดี มีตัวอย่างของผู้ที่ทำแล้วประสบความสำเร็จ และตัวอย่างของนักการเมืองหรือคนสำคัญระดับโลก หรือระดับประเทศ ที่เขาพูดหรือจัดการกับปัญหาใหญ่ๆ อย่างไร ก็เป็นสิ่งที่ดีและดีที่เขาเน้นว่า ต้องมาจากความจริงใจ ไม่เสแสร้งหรือแกล้งพูดเพื่อให้ได้สิ่งที่ต้องการ หลักการโดยรวมแล้ว ถ้าเคยอ่านหนังสือพุทธมาเยอะๆ ก็จะรู้สึกว่าไม่มีอะไรใหม่ คนที่ถือหลักเมตตา มีศีลข้อสาม พูดจาดี ไม่โกหก หยาบคาย เสียดสี ก็ต้องมีปิยวาจาอยู่พอควรแล้ว ยิ่งหลักกฎแห่งกรรม ต้องการรับสิ่งไร ก็จงทำกับผู้อื่นเช่นนั้น มันอยู่ในแกนของศาสนาเราหนังสือนี้ก็เน้นว่า คนแต่ละคนนั้น ไม่มีใครชอบการตำหนิ ไม่ว่าจะดุด่าพนักงานเท่าไร จะไม่มีผลทำให้เขาปรับปรุงตัว หรือทำงานดีขึ้นได้ หากตรงกันข้าม การชื่นชม การรู้จักโน้มน้าวจิตใจอย่างสร้างสรรค์ ทำให้คนอยากร่วมมือร่วมใจทำในสิ่งที่เขาควรจะทำมากกว่าหลายเท่านักอ่านแล้วยิ่งเน้นให้เรารู้สึกในสิ่งที่เชื่ออยู่แล้ว จากพุทธวจนะที่ว่า "วาจาไม่ดี ไม่ควรพูด ไม่ว่ากาลไหนๆ" เพราะไม่มีใครต้องการฟังคำด่าจริงๆ แม้ว่ามันจะเป็นความจริง แต่ไม่ถูกหูเขา คนเราก็ไม่ต้องการฟัง แต่ถ้าเราเห็นข้อดีของเขา และรู้ว่าตนเองก็มีข้อเสีย ไม่ตั้งหน้าตำหนิเขาฝ่ายเดียว แต่ขอความร่วมมือ ให้เขาลองมองมุมนี้ดู ปรับปรุงตรงนั้นเพิ่ม แล้วจะดีขึ้นไหม เขาจะลดการต่อต้านและอยากทำตามมากขึ้นนี่คือวิธีการที่นุ่มนวลและเป็นมิตร หลายครั้งในตัวอย่างในเล่มก็พิสูจน์ว่าสามารถทำให้คนที่ตั้งป้อมรังเกียจ จะฟ้องร้อง หันมาเห็นมุมที่ตัวเองผิด และขอโทษปรับให้ถูกได้ เพียงเพราะมีคนฟังแล้วเข้าใจเขา มีศิลปะการพูดการทำตามหลักการในเล่มนี้ คิดว่าดีอยู่มาก (ดีกว่าไม่มีหลักอะไร) แต่สำหรับแก่นแท้แล้ว หลักธรรมในพุทธศาสนาดีกว่า เพราะมาจากจิตใจ เริ่มต้นที่จิตใจจริงๆ แล้วการกระทำ คำพูด มันก็ออกมาเองโดยธรรมชาติ แม้สถานการณ์เปลี่ยนไปก็จะใช้หลักเดิมได้ตลอดในเล่มนี้เหมือนแค่วิธีการ ยังไม่ไปถึงระดับจิตใจจริงๆ ดังนั้นถ้ามีสถานการณ์ที่ต่างออกไป ก็ยังไม่สามารถตอบโจทย์ได้ทั้งหมดค่ะ ในอีกแง่ก็คือ วิธีการในหนังสือนี้ดี และลองใช้ดีกว่าไม่ใช้ แต่ถามว่าจะได้ผลร้อยเปอร์เซ็นต์ไหม คงจะไม่ และถ้าไม่ได้ใช้กับสถานการณ์อย่างธุรกิจหรือการเมืองแล้ว บางสถานการณ์อาจจะใช้ไม่ได้บางสิ่งบางอย่างดูล้าสมัยนิดหน่อย เพราะเป็นเรื่องที่ อเมริกันรับมาทำกันจนค่อนข้างเฝือไปแล้ว และสอนกันไปทั่วโลกแล้วด้วย เช่นการจำชื่อแขก จำชื่อคนให้ได้แม่นยำ พอโรงแรมชั้นหนึ่งหลายแห่งฝึกพนักงานให้ทำได้กันเป็นส่วนใหญ่แล้ว การทำเช่นนี้ก็ไม่ใช่สิ่งพิเศษที่จะทำให้คนทั่วไปซาบซึ้งแบบสมัยก่อนอีกต่อไป การเริ่มต้นพูดทำนองว่า ผมเชื่อว่าคุณเป็นคนใจกว้าง ดังนั้นคุณคงจะยอมรับฟังเรื่อง...ได้ พอคนพูดกันเยอะๆ แล้ว มันก็เหมือนเป็นประโยคที่คนฟังปุ๊บรู้สึกทันทีว่าเป็นรูปแบบละ ไม่ได้ออกมาจากใจจริงหลักฮาวทูทั้งหลายนี้ จึงยังไม่มีเล่มไหนที่เราจะประทับใจได้จริงๆ เลย (แม้จะถือว่าค่อนข้างดีมากอย่างเล่มนี้ก็ตาม) เพราะรู้สึกว่าหลักธรรมนั้นเหนือกว่าและครอบคลุมไปทุกสาขา ไม่ว่าจะเอาไปในการประกอบอาชีพไหน หรือกิจกรรมใดในชีวิต ก็ใช้ได้หมดและปรับใช้ได้ไม่ล้าสมัยเลย เพราะจับที่แก่นหรือหัวใจของธรรมชาติมนุษย์ไว้ได้แล้วนั่นเอง
So very helpful

Really inspirational. I really liked all his references to Abraham Lincoln and Al Capone. Interesting times back then but very applicable to our day as well. really good advice--now if I could apply it every day :P

Although it's been ten years since I've read this book, I still remember how much it influenced me and helped me break out of my shy little shell. This book helps people to attain social confidence, not through tricks or smarminess, but through things that actually just make you a nicer person to be around and make others more comfortable.A must-read for everyone, but especially anyone who wants or needs to do work involving people or self-promotion.I remember as a teenager making fun of my sister's friend, a DJ, for having this book. He just smiled and said, "You should read it." That really shut me up and made me think about how much more popular he was than me, and a few years later, I saw the book, remembered that day, and read it.Sometimes I think I really need to read this every year!
A well written book. Enjoyed reading it...

Interessante abordagem sobre o trato com as pessoas, apesar dos exemplos um tanto fora da realidade brasileira do século XXI. U livro que ensina a pensar um pouco mais no outro, pensar pelo lado do outro para conseguir o que quer de maneira menos agressiva.

A very good book, truly a classic that everyone (and not only business people or salesman!) should read at least once.Carnegie is convinced success depends more on interpersonal relationships than on academic/technical knowledge and, therefore, outlines here some principles regarding how to make, lead and manage such relationships. It is NOT about flattery, selfishness or manipulative hypocrisy -far from that, it's about empathy and consideration for each others. That sounds cheesy but, honestly, how many of us really apply or know how to apply such an approach in our dealing with others? Then here you are: this book contains tips for everyone.

If ever there were a book I didn't especially want people seeing on my nightstand, here it be. It just feels like it begs for an explanation, am I right? Anyway, I picked up a pretty beat up 1980-something version, half-expecting to laugh my way through the first chapter and then shelf it, but I quickly found my self oddly engrossed. How little I'd known of the very basics of carrying on. The common sense in this little gem is kind of amazing, and Carnegie is darn likeable. I mean really- if you want people to do nice things for you even when you can offer nothing in return, behave more like a dog and be extra happy to see them and super interested in them. I mean I'm majorly paraphrasing here, but lovingly so. If it were any more simple, I'd think I were missing something. If you let it, this stuff can actually help you succeed. If that last thing I said about the dog makes it sound like a manual for selling yourself, rest assured that Carnegie stresses sincerity as much as skill. If you think your twenty-something college professor has more valuable things to tell you than your grandmother, and if you've really nothing to learn from anyone anyway, don't read this book- not that you'd dream of it, of course. But I certainly recommend it to those not drowning in haughty pretense and looking to actually learn something, and particularly to the socially clueless like myself. Happy reading!
Readable book when you have spare time...

Useful read. Finished reading this back in December, and I still think about it. A better title may be "How to keep the friends you have by being less of a d***." While the concepts make sense, it's hard to override instincts and put the concepts into practicePros:* Well presented and structured* Useful information, particularly the section on argumentsCons:* A bit repetitive at times* Inconsistencies between the start of a chapter, and the conclusion* A lot of anecdotes tend to come across as lucky occurrences than deterministic outcomes from following the advice in the book.Would I recommend this book to others? - I already have, but with a grain of salt. This book is great at telling you what NOT to do, but not so great at telling you what to do instead.

This is a hilarious page-turner and though the title is a little quaint and corny, Dale Carnegie's enthusiasm is infectious and seems to capture well what must have been a very powerful speaking style.

Very interesting stuff! I will definitely have to try it out. Apparently this book changed my brother's life so I had to read it, and then some old guys on a plane were like, "Hey, she's reading Dale Carnegie!" Some of the stuff is a bit dated, and I wish the material was better organized, but it's still great advice for just being a good person.

I loved this book. What a novel idea to actually listen and care about people and stop being so selfish. And yes I totally agree 90% of a job is people skills, not technical. There are some people who really only care about themselves and they can and do use the techniques laid out in this book to manipulate people but they are fakes, cowards and truly unhappy people deep down. Side note - for a great read on the subject of selfish, manipulative and entitled people read Aaron James' book titled "Assholes".

Some truths are timeless. This is a foundational book for all salesmen, negotiators, media people, politicians, and those who want to be a good friend to anyone. Even though originally published in 1953, it has bee reprinted dozens of times as recently as April 2006! Very practical information for all that will improve your relationships and change your life. Really! Not just a clever statement. A GREAT BOOK

A classic book with great tips and helpful reminders with interpersonal relationships. the key word is reminders. He is not trying to teach us common courtesy; he is teaching the importance of consistency

Dale Carnegie's How to Win Friends and Influence People gives you different sets of principles for how to interact with people, create acquaintance and friendships, persuade someone to your opinion, and become a leader. As for how to interact with people, he advises people (1) not to criticize, condemn, or complain; (2) to give honest and sincere appreciation; and (3) to arouse in other people an eager want, meaning something like convincing people of why they really should want to do what they claim to want to do or why they should do something that you, as someone persuading them, would like them to do. Regarding the other areas the book is about, you can read the list of principles here on the Wikipedia page.Although the book was helpful in terms of its advice, it did offer a lot more principles than most people, myself included, could memorize. And the title, unfortunately, suggests manipulation even though that is not really the point of the book at all; for example, it would be hard to argue that the book is trying to manipulate people when one of its principles for making acquaintances and friends is become genuinely interested in other people. Despite these areas, though, the many principles and the titles, the folksy stories and verbal illustrations of the principles made the book fun. By the way, to be perfectly honest, I listened to this in audiobook, and if you can get it in that format, and listen to it in your spare time, I'd recommend it, because of the warm voice of the narrator.
A good read and looking forward to read his other book collections

I don't usually like business books but this one was brief and to the point. I've heard a lot of people recommend this over the years and I finally decided to check it out. All the advice is practical; the key is remembering to apply it in your day-to-day interactions. A lot of the examples are a little dated, but I think that's what gives it its charm -- if they were modern examples I think it'd be less interesting.

Some of the examples how to talk to people are a bit naive and might even be counterproductive. Nonetheless, most of advice given in this book are still relevant to this date and can largely improve both your personal and business relationships.

Everything Dale Carnegie says in this book is common sense, but it is a REALLY good reminder of how to treat people and get what you want out of business or personal transactions while still maintaining good relationships with people. I will keep this on hand and listen to it again in a year or so when I need to remind myself of the points he makes. Basically it boils down to always put yourself in the other person's shoes, be positive not angry or irate with people, and treat others with respect. The principles are so good, that I am going to copy/paste the outline here so I have them saved:Fundamental Techniques in Handling People1. Don't criticize.2. Give honest and sincere appreciation.3. Arouse in the other person an eager want.✦ Six ways to make people like you1. Become genuinely interested in other people.2. Smile.3. Remember a person's name.4. Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves.5. Talk in terms of the other person's interests.6. Make the other person feel important - and do it sincerely.✦ Win people to your way of thinking1. The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.2. Show respect for the other person's opinions. Never say, "You're wrong."3. If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.4. Begin in a friendly way.5. Get the other person saying "yes, yes" immediately.6. Let the other person do a great deal of the talking.7. Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers.8. Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view.9. Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires.10. Appeal to the nobler motives.11. Dramatize your ideas.12. Throw down a challenge.✦ Be a Leader1. Begin with praise and honest appreciation.2. Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly.3. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.4. Ask questions instead of giving direct orders.5. Let the other person save face.6. Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement.7. Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to.8. Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct.9. Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest.

I listened to the audio book. The version I have is like a 7 hour book from iTunes. I used to listen to it while I was walking around London. I'm not sure if the content of my audio book is exactly the same as this print book but I'll review it here anyway.I didn't think that I would learn anything from this book that I didn't already know. I thought it would just be common sense. What I was shocked to learn is that bad people don't know that they are bad people. Bad people actually think they are good people. Even murderers think they are good people and will defend and justify their actions. That really shocked me. It was hard to believe at first but now it makes sense and helps me understand people better.Reading this book has helped me get along with people that I wouldn't normally like or have anything in common with. I used to just avoid people like that and not talk to them. But now I can have pleasant conversations with people who I have little to nothing in common with. I recently talked for hours to someone I have nothing in common with at all. We are very opposite and he is the type of person who is extremely opinionated, states his opinions as facts, and thinks everyone who doesn't think like he does is an idiot. Normally I would avoid someone like this or end up in an argument. By using what I learned in this book I had a pleasant conversation with this guy.I'm much better off for having read this book and I would recommend it to anyone. It's nearly impossible to avoid people that you don't like or have anything in common with so this is important stuff to learn.

This is a very insightful and useful book. It offers valuable guidance about how to deal more successfully with other people, even when they are initially reticent or even hostile, and it cites many examples, both from the author's own experience and from history, of the successful application of the principles it espouses.Among them are "Become genuinely interested in other people" rather than just in yourself, "Smile", "Be a good listener..." and so on. In general, Carnegie advocates kindness, generosity of spirit, tolerance and understanding, not only as good in themselves but also as advantageous to the person exhibiting these traits.He has no illusions about human nature. He views people as La Rochefoucauld did--as being motivated chiefly by "amour-propre." And yet, far from causing Carnegie to disdain his fellow man for pettiness or narrow selfishness, this insight makes him more understanding. 'How can we expect people to be different from how they are and must be?', he might ask.But the book has imperfections. Carnegie is quite selective in his use of historical examples, and sometimes badly misrepresents the cases he cites, in his zeal to show historical support for his own methods. For one example, he takes Abraham Lincoln as a model of persuasive power--not mentioning that Lincoln, whatever his oratorical prowess, was unable to persuade Southerners that he was anything other than their bitter foe, intent on undermining their way of life, so that his election prompted a very bloody civil war and, eventually, his own assassination. Certainly Lincoln was an heroic figure who deserves enormous praise for his management of the war and for ending slavery, but he is probably not the best example of the persuasive power of Carnegie-style bonhomie.And Carnegie points to Socrates, too, as a model of his methods, heartily approving of the persuasive power of Socratic dialectic. Yet Carnegie fails to see the irony in this, given that Socrates' methods aroused such bitter hatred in many of his fellow Athenians that they tried him and executed him. Again, Socrates is one of the greatest figures in Western history, and a model of virtue, but is hardly a model to follow if one wishes simply to "win friends".These quibbles aside, however, this book is well worth reading, and is vastly better than the typical self-help book. No less a figure than Warren Buffett has used Carnegie's methods to great success. Buffett is most famous for investing prowess, but equally important to his success has been his ability to manage people, to keep talented people who are already so wealthy that they do not need to work at all, working hard for his company. He does so by following Carnegie's advice, to be lavish with praise and sparing with criticism, thereby arousing in his employees a zeal for their work.I would give this book 4.5 stars if I could.

Be lavish in your praise, and hearty in your approbation. Let the other person save face. You can't win an argument. This book, which is now more than seventy-five years old, has persisted because of its core ideas on how to understand other people in today's society. While some of the writing hasn't aged well due to shifts in socioeconomic situations, the majority of the ideas in this book can be applied rather well to our daily lives.This book can serve several purposes depending on your current situation. For some professionals, like used car salespeople or marketers, this book may read as a manual for how to exploit or move the masses to your point of view. For others, this book may act as a cautionary guide on how to avoid the first group's tactics. And for others still, this book describes honest ways to bolster efficiency at the workplace, at home, and with friends. The key idea I received from this book: no matter how you interact with others, always be genuine. False praise and insincerity are easy to spot, even in an age where so many relationships are abstracted by a digital layer.

Being such a classic book, I figured I had to read this. It was worth it and everyone should probably read it. I think the hidden gem in this book is that there is advice from many famous people in it - either people the author knew directly or those he studied heavily - presidents and other political leaders, millionaires (from the late-1800s and early 1900s, so very successful people), etc. All the concepts are super simple and there are lots of examples of successes implementing the lessons on the book. Sometimes, the examples seems to attribute the success too much to the single tip in that chapter, when I'm sure there are many other factors at play. Especially whenever there was an example of a tip around parent/child issues i.e. getting a kid to eat his veggies was as simple as convincing him that he could 'wallop the daylights out of the bigger kid [bully] someday if he would only eat the things his mother wanted him to eat'.Concepts have been shared in numerous (unrelated) books and training courses over the last ~80 years, as they are mostly just basic interpersonal awareness concepts. But, it's presented so simply and completely, this book is a good read for anyone, regardless of their strength in dealing with people. It still gave me some new ideas, and was a good reminder about some things I easily forget (like pointing out all the good behaviors and progress in my kids, instead of criticizing their misbehavior). Overall, an easy and worthwhile read. If I had a paper version instead of the Kindle copy, I'm sure it would have been dog-eared and highlighted throughout. I expect (hope) to look at my highlighted notes regularly, to remind me of the lessons in this book.

Key principles for social dynamics So, this book was written in the 30s, and is still highly recommended by top performers and influencers in the business arena. Why? Well, after giving it a chance I realized that pretty much of the principles presented in the book are the sum of psychology hacks that are timeless. (Don't be fooled by the old stories and examples about letters written by Lincoln or Roosevelt.)Human behavior and social dynamics is the name of the game in most of the things we tackle, in business and in life, and after being in the corporate world for more than 10 years and as a sales person, you learn a thing or two. I wish I had read this book earlier. So, get in it, finish it and you won't regret it. Great buy.

Practical and influential in it's own right, this classic best seller remains one of the top books for understanding the realm of influence, relationship and success. I have come against a Christian response to this book and it's measure of success (being fueled by personal and the world's measuring stick instead of God's), but the truth is I see I lot of overlap and a lot of great principles that can help anyone, Christian or not. True, to get the most out of this book we must be willing to see read it as a commentary on what is largely self driven and within our own realm of control and influence. But the question of what we desire to influence those around us with is where the conversation goes further. This is simply a book that helps to expose exactly what sits at the inner core of all human emotion and motivation, and how to tailor that for your own purpose.The book deals with the questions of how to make people like you, how to win people over to your way of thinking and how to influence without the anger and resentment that can follow reaction to ambitious leadership. On the surface perhaps these ideas might come across as a bit offensive and off putting to some. After all, understanding that we all are bred to manipulate in some form or fashion opens up the realization that we have also been manipulated by others to their point of view. But underneath this book simply exposes an uncomfortable reality and challenges the notion that manipulation and influence needs to be negative. And once we are able to come face to face with that, we then are able to ask where we want to sit ourselves and what we want to do with those personal ideas that are burning a hole in side of ourselves. It puts everyone on the same playing field and simply separates based on those who choose to be influenced or those who chose to influence, and then looks at the guiding principles that make up those who can influence well. We all have the choice of what we want to do with this truth and realization, and this book is a helpful tool for navigating that tricky ground of winning people and influencing them effectively.

How to Win Friends and Influence People is full of practical advice that appears obvious and self-explanatory on the surface. However, so few people actually obey all of its guidelines that it is a valuable book for anyone seeking to improve themselves. From practical ways to avoid criticism to getting the best of any argument, Carnegie touches on how to navigate a wide spectrum of human interactions. One of the best things about this book is that every chapter has a wealth of anecdotes and stories instead of just instructional text.
very good, ideas wise.

This book was actually pretty darn good. That's saying something for me, as I tend to get annoyed with self-help books. Mr. Carnegie is not presumptuous in the slightest. He lets the stories and experiences shared in this book speak for themselves. This aspect of his writing really connected with me, as I never felt him getting on his soap box, or anything of the sort. Several times, he makes comments like "Preposterous? Crazy? Well let's learn about the experience of such and such a person who used this very process...." It was also quite an entertaining read - his writing style is one that one can keep you interested -which you can really appreciate in a self-help book. (I am usually falling asleep reading these types of books...) Part of what made it so easy to read was that there really wasn't too much filler, which seems to plague books of this genre. That being said, there was SOME filler - and I think that a large portion of the end of the book could be condensed. He also seems to only provide suggestions on how to handle situations when the people involved are all generally good. He does acknowledge that these methods won't work for everyone (I can think of a few in my life), but doesn't provide alternate suggestions or methods on how to handle these "special" individuals. Perhaps this is approached in one of his other works.Negative points aside, this was really the best self-help book that I have read - light years more entertaining and helpful than others of the genre. If you are looking to read a self-help book, this is probably the one of the few that you can finish without feeling like you wasted your time.

Despite its manipulative-sounding title, this book is about genuinely improving your social skills and winning people to your way of thinking. Although I generally agree with his principles, I think Carnegie makes following them sound too easy.Carnegie states that 15% of success is due to technical knowledge, and the other 85% is due to personality and leadership. He says that the #1 secret to success in dealing with people is having a sympathetic grasp of the other person’s point of view. He talks a lot about respecting and understanding other people, and quotes Ralph Waldo Emerson: "Every man I meet is my superior in some way. In that, I learn of him."Carnegie also talks a lot about praise; he says that praise is more effective than criticism for changing behavior and winning people over, so you should be “hearty in your approbation and lavish in your praise.”The book includes lessons from people like Jesus, Confucius, Buddha, Abraham Lincoln, Andrew Carnegie, Ben Franklin, John Rockefeller, Charles Schwab, and J.P. Morgan. Carnegie provides anecdotes of his own experiences, and those of the people who took his courses.I first read this book when co-workers suggested I improve my social skills, because I received many recommendations for this book. I re-read it because the lessons are so important and worthwhile.Below are the book's principles, along with my notes.Fundamental Techniques in Handling People1. Don't criticize, condemn, or complain.• Criticism is futile.2. Give honest and sincere appreciation.• Avoid flattery.3. Arouse in the other person an eager want.• Salespeople need to show how their products and services solve customers’ problems• Each party should gain; there must be mutual benefit.Six Ways to Make People Like You1. Become genuinely interested in other people.• “You can make more friends in two months by becoming more interested in other people than you can in two years by trying to get people interested in you”• Greet people with animation and enthusiasm. When someone calls on the phone, sound like you’re pleased.2. Smile.• A facial expression is more important than clothes.• Encouragement is more effective than punishment.• Don’t feel like smiling? Force yourself; feeling follows action.3. Remember that a man's Name is to him the sweetest and most important sound in any language.• To remember names, tie the name to a person’s features, use the person’s name in conversation, and write and memorize the name.4. Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves.• To be a good conversationalist, listen and pay attention.• To be interesting, be interested.5. Talk in the terms of the other man's interest.6. Make the other person feel important and do it sincerely.• The law of human conduct: always make the other person feel important.• Follow the Golden Rule: "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you".Twelve Ways to Win People to Your Way of Thinking1. Avoid arguments.• You can’t win an argument. Even if you win, you make your opponent feel inferior, so you lose.2. Show respect for the other person's opinions. Never tell someone they are wrong.3. If you're wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.4. Begin in a friendly way.• "'A drop of honey catches more flies than a gallon of gall.' So with men. If you would win a man to your cause, first convince him that you are his sincere friend." – Lincoln5. Start with questions the other person will answer yes to.• The more yeses you can get at the outset, the more likely the person is to accept your ultimate proposal.6. Let the other person do the talking.• “If you want enemies, excel your friends; but if you want friends, let your friends excel you”.7. Let the other person feel the idea is his/hers.8. Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view.9. Sympathize with the other person.10. Appeal to noble motives.• Treat people as if they are honest and fair.11. Dramatize your ideas.12. Throw down a challenge.• Use showmanship when selling or convincing.Be a Leader: How to Change People Without Giving Offense or Arousing Resentment1. Begin with praise and honest appreciation.• Use "and", not "but" as your conjunction between praise and criticism. Give praise, then say “and”, then give criticism/correction. Don’t give praise, say “but”, then criticize; it cheapens the praise.2. Call attention to other people's mistakes indirectly.3. Talk about your own mistakes first.4. Ask questions instead of directly giving orders.• People are more likely to accept an order if they had a part in the decision.5. Let the other person save face.6. Praise every improvement.• Give specific, sincere praise.• Praise is more effective at changing behavior than criticism.7. Give them a fine reputation to live up to.• Praise people, and they’ll feel obligated to live up to their good reputation.8. Encourage them by making their faults seem easy to correct.9. Make the other person happy about doing what you suggest.• Convince people by telling them specifically how they’ll personally benefit.

Encourage others to talk about themselves.5 Talk in terms of the other person's interest.6 Make the other person feel important – and do it sincerely.Twelve Ways to Win People to Your Way of Thinking1 The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.2 Show respect for the other person's opinions. Never say "You're wrong."3 If you're wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.4 Begin in a friendly way.5 Start with questions to which the other person will answer yes.6 Let the other person do a great deal of the talking.7 Let the other person feel the idea is his or hers.8 Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view.9 Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires.10 Appeal to the nobler motives.11 Dramatize your ideas.12 Throw down a challenge.Be a Leader: How to Change People Without Giving Offense or Arousing Resentment1 Begin with praise and honest appreciation.2 Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly.3 Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.4 Ask questions instead of giving direct orders.5 Let the other person save face.6 Praise every improvement.7 Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to.8 Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct.9 Make the other person happy about doing what you suggest.Seven Rules For Making Your Home Life Happier1 Don't nag.2 Don't try to make your partner over.3 Don't criticize.4 Give honest appreciation.5 Pay little attentions.6 Be courteous.7 Read a good book on the sexual side of marriage.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_to_...

One of the example what he quoted is really excellent -"How can we say we have love on our friends, it is whenever our friends talk to us we have to stop our work and then listen to what out friend conveys." He narrated this example with a situation between son and a mother. And by the end of the book he says few principles that every individual should follow to become a Leader. Leader - should always accept his mistakes and then should point out the others mistakes. He should not criticise any one for the mistakes but rather he should praise about the success things and then from those examples he should point to the mistake done by the member.

Interesting book from the self-help department. Surely some helpful things written in it, with nice tips on how to apply certain tricks in dealing with people. Generally, just by rephrasing your thoughts and sentences you can come across in a very different manner. This book gets you to thinking about yourself and encourages self-reflection. However, some of the anecdotes are a bit unrealistic in my opinion. For example, someone has a problem with the insurance company as they don't want to pay the full amount one is owed. Then you go and first make the guy from the company feel important and tell him how helping you will benefit him, and on top of that you mention his great reputation to live up to....and just like magic even the most antagonistic counterparty will do as you would like. Take the lessons and applications with a little pinch of salt.
I don't think Carnegie would be a fan of most people these days.

Published in 1937, it was an overnight hit, eventually selling 15 million copies. Financial success, Carnegie believed, is due 15 percent to professional knowledge and 85 percent to "the ability to express ideas, to assume leadership, and to arouse enthusiasm among people."The book is brilliantly written and opens with fundamental techniques for dealing with people, such as refraining from criticism, expressing sincere appreciation, making people like you by smiling, remembering names, and being a good listener.An excellent read for anyone!

This might be most widely known self-help book, written quite some time ago, and it does share many issues with the genre. There is a set of principles postulated by the author (not through any obvious research process), supported mostly by anecdotal evidence (subject to selection bias) and big success stories (not likely to be reproducible). On a more philosophical level, many of those successes might be individual wins in a zero-sum game, not necessary wins for society.At the same time, being written back in 1936, this book had the luxury of talking about many common sense suggestions. Many of them have found more robust evidence since then, are win-win, easy to practice, and so have high "return on investment" - and it looks like every single such suggestion is mostly ignored today. So, informal by-example treatment might still be valuable, by basically picturing and storing in memory the examples of concrete situation where the principles can be used, therefore making them spring to action in future.
OutstandingThis book is a must read for everyoneYou will find within methods of how to understand and influence people, essential in any time and societyGreat read, thanks.

How to win friends and influence people main pointsCriticising someones work won’t get them to do better but the opposite. By praising it you make the person give 150%, almost always.When motivating someone always discuss about what he gains out of it, how you think of solving his or her problems.The royal road to a person’s heart is to talk about things he or she treasures most.Always try to think from the other person’s point of view. People have 2 needs: understanding one another, their place within the social group and the feeling of importance. If you take sides against them then they react so as to acquire that feeling of importance. If you praise them then they will praise you because by doing so they feel they can easily acquire importance by being in the position as to praise their praiser.When you win or lose an argument you lose. You lose in the long run. Criticism and beating somebody will fuel him or her to take action against you in the future. Sort of like karma…

Perhaps the first, and probably the best of the positive thinking books so beloved by salespersons and businesspeople, keen to further their careers. It is an instruction manual in how to be nice and not nasty, hard-working and not lazy; well-organized and not daft. Whether one should be quite so systematically "nice" in order to manipulate people into giving you good jobs or profitable sales is, however, an interesting ethical point.

:قبل أن تشرع في قراءة الكتاب, هناك ملاحظات أحبذ اعتبارها في حساباتك1- السلوكيات والنصائح الواردة لا يعتمد عليها بالكلية للحصول على أصدقاء من أقرانك, فلكي يقبلك أحدهم كصديق في علاقة طويلة المدى يجب أن تكون شخصاً ذا ثقل, ويحمل مميزات مادية مفيدة تجعله يحتاجك دائماً, وإذا فقدت هذه الميزات فستنطفئ علاقته بك تدريجياً حتى وإن لم يكن يقصد هو ذلك؛ لذا فالعمل على تنمية مهاراتك هو حجر الأساس. 2- يجب أن تبدو السلوكيات التي تنفذها بمظهر السلوكيات المخلصة, فالناس لا يحبون الرياء والمداهنة؛ فذلك يظهرك غالباً كنصاب يعاملهم كأغبياء, وفي أحسن الأحوال تظهر بمظهر النصاب فقط, وفي كل الأحوال سيتلاشى مجهودك المبذول على هذه السلوكيات. وبصفتي الشخصية, لي صديق يحاول دائماً تنفيذ سلوكيات كالمذكورة في الكتاب كإظهار الاهتمام بما يثير اهتمامي, ولكنه لا يفعلها بإخلاص غالباً, فيتحول الأمر إلى مدعاة للشفقة. 3- السلوكيات الواردة ليست بتعاويذ سحرية, فضلاً عن أنها معروفة وقديمة قدم الأزل, ولكن لا يستخدمها الناس عادة في أمورهم اليومية لارتفاع تكلفة الجهد المبذول فيها مقابل العائد البسيط منها نظراً لأن معظم الأشخاص الذين نقابلهم لا فائدة منهم على الإطلاق. وعندما نحتاج أحد هذه السلوكيات لتخطي ورطة مع أحد الأشخاص, تتوه الحلول مننا, وإن وجدناها فليس بمقدورنا تنفيذ ما لم نتعود على فعله تنفيذاً يبدو جيداً. وعليه, فالأعلام الوارد ذكرهم في الكتاب كعباقرة في التعامل مع الناس مثل "روزفلت", يستثمرون جهود ضخمة لتمويل شعبيتهم وسط الناس, وبهذا أصل من جديد إلى إن العبقرية هي مقدرة على الصبر/الاجتهاد.ليس لدي الصبر على كل تلك المشاق لتلقي مشاعر الناس, ومن الجيد أنه ليس لدي رغبة عميقة في استزادة مقدرتي على معاملة الناس بحكم شخصيتي الـ"INTJ-T"  .. وعليه نويت استخدام الكتاب كمرجع, في حال إن تورطت في علاقة مع أحد البشر.4-"moral high ground fags" ككل الكتب التي تتحدث عن سلوك البشر وكيفية استغلاله, لا ينصح به للسادة الـ .5- استخدمه باعتدال, فمعظم السلوكيات تعتمد في تأثيرها على قلة تنفيذ الآخرين لها, وإذ أنت أغرقت الجميع بها, فسوف يتبدد تأثيرها ككل شيء متوفر بسهولة من حولهم مهما كان أهمية ما تقوم به لهم. خذ الماء والهواء كمثال وعبرة.***ترجمة "عبد الله محمد الزيادي" عن "دار الندوة الجديدة" اللبنانية ترجمة جيدة جداً... ترجمة العنوان الرئيسي لـ "كيف تختار الأصدقاء" غير موفق, والعنوان الفرعي "كيف تؤثر في الناس" أكثر تعبيراً عن الكتاب.هناك ترجمات أخرى متوفرة, ولكني لم أطلع عليها.***تماماً ككتاب "دع القلق وتعلم الحياة", يسرد كارنجي الكثير من القصص الحقيقية المسلية لتوضيح نصائحه, ولإعطاء أمثلة عملية نستطيع استغلالها في حياتنا. أذكر منهم قصتان, والأولى منهما تصرفت فيها قليلاً:"إن معظم الشبان الراغبين في الزواج لا يهمهم أن تكون الزوجة المنشودة ربة بيت من الطراز الأول بقدر ما يهمهم أن تشبع غرورهم, وتمنحهم الإحساس بالأهمية والاعتبار!"ولعل هذا هو السر في أن أكثر الفتيات المثقفات يخفقن في الحصول على الأزواج, فإنك قد تدعو الفتاة المثقفة للغداء معك , فلا تلبث أن تتركك وقد تحمست لدراسة التيارات الهامة في الفلسفة المعاصرة - مثلاً- وماذا تكون النتيجة؟ تتناول غداءها بعد ذلك بلا رفيق.ولكنك قد تدعو إلى الغداء فتاة تعمل على الآلة الكاتبة ولم تدرس قط في الجامعة, فلا تلبث أن تثبت نظرها عليك, وتقول لك: "حدثني عن نفسك" وماذا تكون النتيجة؟ سوف تشعر بالأمان في صحبتها, وسوف تقول حتماً في لأصحابك: "صحيح إنها ليست على قدر كبير من الجمال, ولكني ارتحت لها!" منذ وقت قصير, وقع صديق لي في غرام فتاة لم يلبث أن خطبها, وبعد قليل من خطبته, رغبت إليه خطيبته في أن يتعلم الرقص فاستجاب لرغبتها. قال لي وهو يروي القصة: "... والله يعلم أنني كنت في أمس الحاجة إلى دروس الرقص. كنت قد تعلمت الرقص منذ نحو عشرين سنة, فلما عدت إليه, عدت كما بدأته, وقد صارحتني المدرسة الأولى التي قصدت إليها, بهذه الحقيقة سافرة, قالت لي لي إنني على خطأ بيّن, وإنه يجب أن أنسى ما تعلمته في الماضي وأن أبدأ من جديد! ولكن هذا اقتضاني مجهوداً كبيراً, ولم يكن لدي دافع يدفعني إلى مواصلة التعليم فتركتها!. "ولعل المعلمة الثانية كذبت علي, ولكني فضلتها! قالت لي إن رقصي قديم العهد بعض الشيء, ولكن المبادئ في جوهرها صحيحة. وأكدت أنني لن ألقى عناء في تعلم بعض الخطوات الجديدة."لقد بثت المعلمة الأولى اليأس في نفسي بتأكيدها لأخطائي, أما الثانية فقد فعلت العكس تماماً: امتدحت الشيء الوحيد الصحيح في رقصي, وهونت كثيراً من شأن أخطائي.وكانت لا تفتأ تقول لي: إن لك أذناً موسيقية .. إنك راقص موهوب. "وبرغم إيماني بأنني كنت – وسأظل – راقصاً من الدرجة الرابعة, إلا أنني كنت أتشكك أحيانا وأقول لنفسي : ربما كانت تعني ما تقول!. والواقع أنني كنت أنقدها المال بسبب ما تواليني به من تشجيع وتقدير!"

I'll admit I was a sceptic, but I really enjoyed this and found it very useful. It's basically a guide on good manners, developing empathy, and not being a selfish arsehole – the added benefits of which are that people want to help people who help them. If you're trying to build a career (particularly in the arts, academia or any field where networking is important), then give this a go.

I've been hesitant to read this for a long time, as I believed it would just be about manipulating and influencing people to your own gain. It wasn't like that all - in fact if I could summarise this book into a simple sentence it would be this:'Help others and think about their needs before your own, and you will be amazed at how well it works out for you.'It's not really a self-help book, it's more of a help-others book! I loved the message and the motivations behind this book. I really believe that the world would be a better place if more people read this.On a technical level, I usually love Dale Carnegie's communication style in his books, and this is no exception. The whole book is full of stories and real-life examples. It's very easy to read and gives you a good summary of each of his points at the end - thanks very much! Great book, highly recommend it.

While some of the stuff is outdated, such as I read in a review - calling out everyone's name while talking to them, isn't gonna get you anywhere - but it gives a brief and interesting insight to interpersonal interaction. and yes, this might be aimed a little bit towards sales persons and management executives and it's often pushing things over the edge, but then again, it is better than any 'management advice 101' book I've come across.

Powerful, quick read. The detractors of this book are taking the information within it too literally, and that is a losing gambit from the get go. The power of this book comes in the form of inspiration and galvanization, not as a step-by-step guide to get people to like you. If you read and follow this book literally, you will come across as a good faker, patronizer, or manipulator.But read between the lines and you start to understand that the greatest ways to make people like you and to get ahead in life is to change, fundamentally, your view on human relationships. It is to put others' interests in front of your own not simply to get something out of them, but to lead a happier life with more success in sales or other avenues. Basically, this is not a guide so much as it is a wake-up call. The only way you can change how the world perceives you is to make a positive change within yourself, and this work gives you many anecdotes and ideas on why and how to make that change. Going up to someone and flattering them is pretentious and patronizing and will never work. Understanding that everyone in this world loves a genuine compliment and loves being recognized, including yourself, will allow you to naturally empathize with people when interacting with them. This is just one of many lessons this short book has taught me.Highly Recommended.
it was quiet interesting and very enlightening.

How To Win Friends and Influence People by Dale Carnegie is a classic. I have been told over and over again (especially within the business world) that this is a must read book (ironically, for how much this book is recommended, it is rarely followed). I can understand why it is a classic, it is certainly sound advice, but a lot of it also strikes me as fairly common sense, aka the Golden Rule.The book is divided into three parts covering the following 30 principles: Don’t criticize, condemn, or complain. 
   Give honest and sincere appreciation. 
   Arouse in the other person an eager need or want. 
   Become genuinely interested in other people. 
   Smile. 
   Remember that a person’s name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language. 
   Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves. 
   Talk in terms of the other person’s interests. 
   Make the other person feel important – and do it sincerely. 
   The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it. 
   Show respect for other person’s opinions. Never say, “You’re wrong.” 
   If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically. 
   Begin in a friendly way. 
   Get the other person saying “yes, yes” immediately. 
   Let the other person do a a great deal of the talking. 
   Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers. 
   Try honestly to see things from the other persons point of view. 
   By synthetic with the other person’s ideas and desires. 
   Appeal to the other nobler motives. 
   Dramatize your ideas. 
   Throw down a challenge. 
   Begin with praise and honest appreciation. 
   Call attention to people’s mistakes indirectly. 
   Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person. 
   Ask questions instead of giving direct orders. 
   Let the other person save face. 
   Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement. Be “hearty in your appreciation and lavish in your praise.” 
   Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to. 
   Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct. 
   Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest. 
  It's not a long book, and I think reading the book over a month, a principle a day, is definitely worth your time. It'll give you food for thought, or at least remind you of some principles you might have forgotten. Quotes I have had some interesting correspondence with Lewis Lawes, who was warden of New York’s infamous Sing Sing prison for many years, on this subject, and he declared that ‘few of the criminals in Sing Sing regard themselves as bad men. They are just as human as you and I. So they rationalise, they explain. They can tell you why they had to crack a safe or be quick on the trigger finger. Most of them attempt by a form of reasoning, fallacious or logical, to justify their antisocial acts even to themselves, consequently stoutly maintaining that they should never have been imprisoned at all.’(This actually reminds me about the book; Mistakes Were Made (But Not By Me) which deals with logical fallacies and how we justify past mistakes and errors).Dr. Dewey said that the deepest urge in human nature is ‘the desire to be important.’You can make more friends in two months by becoming interested in other people than you can in two years by trying to get other people interested in you.
One of the finest book for practical guidance in life I have read in childhood like a Bible!

read this again in 2010, and realized I had put a lot of these principles into practice in the almost 10 years since my first reading of it. Many of the examples are outdated, and involved military sphere as opposed to real world scenarios.

In this classic book, Carnegie emphasizes the importance of genuine empathy when dealing with others in both professional and personal relationships. Here are a few quotes that stood out to me: --"A hen has to lay eggs, a cow has to give milk, and a canary has to sing. But a dog makes his living by giving you nothing but love." --"A great man shows his greatness by the way he treats little men." --"If you want to be a good conversationalist, be an attentive listener."

This book is one of the staples of the personal development literature, and it proclaims a positive message which is not heard often enough: Become GENUINELY interested in people.This one sentence captures the essence of this book, and it is a fundamental paradigm shift that will revolutionize the way you interact with people, to greater mutual satisfaction.

Dale Carnegie's book is a classic must-read. A book about social interaction concepts that, although simple, are essential to understanding how people work. If you systematically apply the concepts taught, you'll notice your network not just grow in size, but the quality of your relationships grow much deeper. Carnegie introduced a simple concept and then backs it up with factual examples. One concept, for example, is to gain a genuine interest in what interests someone ELSE. Abraham Lincoln used to invite people over to his home for dinner, and the night before would stay up educating himself on a topic of interest to his houseguests. The next day, as you'd expect, his guests enjoyed a great time filled with riveting conversation about what was interesting to HIM. Apart from few of the concepts being quite simple, my only serious concern with this book and the reason for the four stars is that IT IS SO CORNY, totally in line with the genre of books written in the 1930s. Every page I feel like I'm talking to a sales guy and he's not letting me get a word in. I still strongly recommend this book to all who may be interested, but be warned that you have to get passed this corny 1930s writing style in order to give the book merit. Hopefully it'll be easier for you than it was for me.

This is a hard one for me to review. On one hand it has a lot of incredible advice that I have found to be true especially for a book as old as it is. On the other hand, much of Carnegie's writing comes across as manipulative. One of the truthful statements he makes is "When dealing with people, let us remember we are not dealing with creatures of logic." and overall the book is his summary of how to get these illogical humans to do what you want. This illogical human has crazy ideals that one day people will be a little more real and genuine and thus I can't say I love everything he writes. Regardless, this is definitely a worthwhile read.

Great (4.5)--A must read for anyone looking to improve their social skills. Actually, this should be a required read for everyone, period. Unless you're a hermit, this book really makes you see social dynamics in a whole new light. Many people might think that all the principles delineated in the book are "common sense" and "obvious." But really, it's one thing to understand and another to be able to practice it. You can read book after book on how to play golf and not be able to play at all, even though you "understand" it and every move makes sense to you.Understanding and doing are completely different, and it's when you do actually put the principles to use that you see the results. It's unbelievable how these simple, commonsensical principles are NOT practiced by people. And it's amazing how actually using them in your daily life produces results you have never expected before.The only complaint I have for this excellent book is that its later part didn't have enough concrete examples to illustrate how to use the principles (thus the 4.5 it gets). Other than that, all the anecdotes were fascinating, principles well-explained and well-organized, and every bit of information was useful to the highest degree. I haven't come across a book that's so simple in its contents and yet so useful.HIghly recommended.

This book is important.It's breezy, applicable to any pursuit, and it's filled with quaint, old-timey language. And because it's so wisdom-packed and I'm such a slow study, I plan to re-read it like once a year.

The poor reviews of this book are amusing, claiming this book wants to turn you into a manipulator, not a friendly person. Perhaps they see it that way, and I can see why they might, but the message I got from this book was the power of positivity. Dale Carnegie points out how the application of a positive mindset, that looks out for positives instead of negatives, can vastly improve your life and those around you. It does not encourage manipulation, it simply points out basics of human psychology, tells you a lot of stories about people who used positive reinforcement instead of negative (something any first year psychology student will learn) and how this led to them achieving their means much more pleasantly than if they had taken a bitter, angry, condescending, forceful or otherwise negative approach. I've read or heard most of these tips myself over the years, but it is eye opening to read everything collated. Old sayings make a lot more sense and I'm hoping to strive to be less of an argumentative person, as I tend to find myself in a lot of arguments that lead to everyone being angry and disappointed. The main point is to be nice. Don't pick fights. Consider the feelings of the other person, be empathetic and put yourself in their shoes before you say a thing. How that is in any way manipulative or bad is not something I can comprehend. If more people socialised in this way the world would be a far more tolerant, pleasant place to exist in.
Um livro intemporal, simples, directo e extremamente útil. Recomendo vivamente!

How to Win Friends and Influence People: http://readwithstyle.wordpress.com/20...According to Goodreads (the Facebook for the reading geeks), I started reading How to Win Friends and Influence People by Dale Carnegie on the 10th of June and I finished it on the 21st of October. No, I didn’t read a page per day, nor did I read it alongside other books. I simply decided to start reading it on the 10th of June and then I gave up. I decided to start reading it several times afterwards and again I gave up after opening it on my Kindle and seeing the first page. What made this book so repulsive to me was the title and the caption below it. How to Win Friends and Influence People sounded to me more like How to Manipulate People into Liking you and How to Manipulate Them into Doing Whatever You Want. Definitely not the type of skill I am looking for in life. I rather not manipulate people into being my friends, I would rather for them to like me for who I am (however difficult that might be). And also, I definitely don’t feel like manipulating people into doing what I want. I would prefer if they do it because I manage to convince them using logic, intelligence, charm, or…well other purely feminine skills :) . Secondly, the caption is a quote from Warren Buffet: “[Carnegie] changed my life”. As much as I admire Mr. Buffet and as much as I enjoy reading his interviews, stories about his life, and memorable quotations, my strong contempt for self-help books is stronger. I have expressed numerous times the view that the self-help authors of the sort of Jorge Bucay, Andy Andrews, etc. do harm people rather than help them. The well digested wisdom of positive thinking and positive affirmations, and the idea of looking at life through pink-coloured glasses doesn’t in any way alter people’s attitude towards that same life. It just teaches them how to focus on changing outward actions instead of inward thoughts.So you would understand my utter unwillingness to read How to Win Friends and Influence People. This book has been recommended to me by one of my best friends for quite a long time and only this recommendation did actually make me finally read it this month. As I have said, books have that special power of finding you exactly when you need them the most. If I had read How to Win Friends and Influence People months back, I doubt I would have been as much impressed by Carnegie as I am now.I am slowly getting to the point that Dale Carnegie’s How to Win Friends and Influence People is not about how to manipulate people. It is rather about how to change your approach towards people and how to understand and fight the natural flaws of the human character, and most importantly of the human ego. Initially, Carnegie started teaching seminars to business people on how to more efficiently deal with their colleagues, on how to tackle conflicts in the working space and on how to win people over to their thinking. These seminars eventually translated into How to Win Friends and Influence People, which lessons can be applied not only with colleagues, but with friends, family, and even with random people you get in contact with.Read more: http://readwithstyle.wordpress.com/20...
I was surprised when I read this that it was written in the 30s. It is still relevant today. I am applying the principles and already seeing results! Impressive!

Okay, you know what, yes. I read How to Win Friends and Influence People. Even though it's corny.There's some good stuff in here. None of of it is ground-breaking but man would it be nice if more people followed some of these suggestions, myself included. So, working on that.Also, a lot of little anecdotes, some of which were terrifying. To get someone to do what you want, make them the leader of the thing! Like the lady who was having problems with boys rushing over her lawn and ruining her garden, so she made the ringleader the Chief Inspector Of Not Screwing Up The Garden. I'm trying to improve my charisma, and I've heard this book recommended many times, so I decided to check it out. It was excellent, with simple, easily understood (though perhaps not so easily implemented) suggestions for improving one's human interactions.The basic point of the book is to suppress one's own ego and to cultivate a genuine interest in other people. The nonfiction book "How to Win Friends and Influence People" is a book that Dale Carnegie wrote to give you tips on how to better yourself with your friends and others involved in your everyday life. He starts by giving you techniques on how to handle people and ends with showing you how to become a leader.The theme of this book is that you can always find things to help your social skills. Throughout the book, Carnegie teaches you essential "do's" and "don't's" when it comes to bettering your social life and overall outlook in life. Carnegie's style of this book is listing, he uses listing by cutting his main points into parts and his parts into chapters. This style gives you the most important points that he is trying to get you to understand. The style of this book is a narration because it goes in order on what you must do first to achieve a better overall social appearance and better social skills. I think that this book was very eye opening and has changed my view points socially as well as ways that I can influence people. This book was a different read for me for sure but I was quite pleased with what this book left me with. I would not change anything about this book because it is so well written and I think that anyone who is trying to better themselves socially.

I finished this as an audiobook a year ago now, gave it two stars and generally wasn't very impressed. Time wore on. Through some glitch on my iPod, whenever my audiobook of choice ended, chapters of this would pop up again, and again, and again. Sometimes I was so bored I listened, and you have to give it to the Caesar, some of the examples were rather funny.I started applying some of the stuff, which was rather basic, and it worked. While I didn't have any major issues with the people beside me, I wasn't exactly enamored with society and when miscommunications happened I wasn't stellar in dealing with them. Long story short, people were generally separated in those who could do damage and those who couldn't and the general approach was to treat with both as little as possible.I won't give it away, because you can't take the main 20-ish pieces of advice in the book without the book. I can tell you that my writing, which could have been pigeon-holed into condensed, succinct or sarcastic has started to develop a rather human tone on the way and while I still don't speak in public as well or as often as I should, I am more fluent, confident and it feels like less of a burden.

My First Dale Carnegie book and I must admit I am thoroughly impressed with what a mere 300 odd pages book has to offer.How to Win Friends and Influence People was recommended to me by my friend-cum-colleague Chintan Bhatt. Sadly, it took close to 2 weeks to finish reading this book as I was reading through an e-book and e-books really do slow down my pace of reading.My job requires me to converse with Directors and Senior-most Managers from the Corporate Biggies across the globe which I must confess tends to get unnerving. I mean, okay, it is one thing to manage to squeeze two minutes out of their precious time for yourself and an altogether different thing to make them listen to what I wish to convey and demand of them.It is tough and moreso when you do not have a tactic on hand to go about successfully achieving your goal. During a casual discussion, I voiced out my concerns as to how it is next to impossible to speak to the concerned person and get your job done through them. That's when Chintan mentioned to me that I should read this book if I wish to make my clients want to do what I want. And it sure is an immense help toward changing the way you look at things and improving the way you interact with people.Effective conversation is essential in professional as well as personal life. And the most important driving factor is selfless-interaction. Being kind and nice is the key to successful interaction and with exemplary instances does Dale elaborate them. These few lines are stuck in my memory even though I finished the book long back
“It isn't what you have or who you are or where you are or what you are doing that makes you happy or unhappy. It is what you think about it.”
It is not meant for a particular age or group of people but useful for everyone. A must read if you feel that your conversation with someone is leading you nowhere. Try this book and feel the difference yourself.

Overall: A well written book with a lot of examples, including many of good folks from the history and many without any citation, but none-the-less seem real. The examples are written so that the message goes across well. Repetition is avoided. The stuff mentioned is pretty obvious and simple, but important and often ignored. Worth reading multiple times as the preface recommends. TEXT DELETED105	SIX WAYS TO MAKE PEOPLE LIKE YOUPRINCIPLE 1: Become genuinely interested in other people. Encourage others to talk about themselves. PRINCIPLE 5: Talk in terms of the other person’s interests. PRINCIPLE 6: Make the other person feel important–and do it sincerely. 110	You cannot win an argumentWhy not let him save his face? He didn’t ask for your opinion. He didn’t want it. Why argue with him? Always avoid the acute angle. Don’t forget this lesson! I have come to the conclusion that there is only one way under high heaven to get the best of an argument—and that is to avoid it. You can’t win an argument. You can’t because if you lose it, you lose it; and if you win it, you lose it. Why? Well, suppose you triumph over the other man and shoot his argument full of holes and prove that he is non compos mentis. Then what? You will feel fine. But what about him? You have made him feel inferior. You have hurt his pride. He will always resent your triumph and “a man convinced against his will is of the same opinion still…” 112	Which would you rather have, an academic theatrical victory or a person’s good will? You can seldom have both. Buddha said, “Hatred is never ended by hatred but by love,” and a misunderstanding is never ended by an argument but by tact, diplomacy, conciliation, and a sympathetic desire to see the other person’s viewpoint. Better give your path to a dog than be bitten by him in contesting for the right. Even killing the dog would not cute the bite. 114	How to keep a disagreement from becoming an argument:1.	Welcome the disagreement: Remember the slogan, “When two partners always agree, one of them is not necessary.” If there is some point you haven’t thought about, be thankful if it is brought to your attention. Perhaps this disagreement is your opportunity to be corrected before you make a serious mistake. 2.	Distrust your first instinctive impressions: Our first natural reaction in a disagreeable situation is to be defensive. Be careful. Keep calm and watch out for your first reaction. It may be you at your worst, not at your best. 3.	Control your temper: Remember, you can measure the size of a person by what makes him or her angry. 4.	Listen first; Give your opponents a chance to talk. Let them finish. Do not resist, defend, or debate. This only raises barriers. Try to build bridges of understanding. Don’t build higher barriers of misunderstanding. 5.	Look for areas of agreement: When you have heard your opponents out, dwell first on the points and areas on which you agree. 6.	Be honest: Look for areas where you can admit error and say so. Apologize for your mistakes. It will help disarm your opponents and reduce defensiveness. 7.	Promise to think over your opponents’ ideas and study them carefully: and mean it! Your opponents may be right. It is a lot easier at this stage to agree to think about their points than to move rapidly ahead and find yourself in a position where your opponents can say: “We tried to tell you, but you wouldn’t listen.” 8.	Thank your opponents sincerely for their interest: Anyone who takes the time to adisagree with you is interested in the same things you are. Think of them as people who really want to help you, and you may turn your opponents into friends. 9.	Postpone actions to give both sides time to think through the problem: Suggest that a new meeting be held later that day or the next day, when all the facts may be brought to bear to preparation for this meeting, ask yourself some hard questions. Could my opponents be right? Partly right? Is there truth or merit in their position or argument? Is my reaction one that will relieve the problem or will it just relieve any frustration? Will my reaction drive my opponents further away or draw them closer to me? Will my reaction elevate the estimation good people have of me? Will I win or lose? What price will I have to pay if I win? If I am quiet about it, what the disagreement blow over? Is this difficult situation an opportunity for me? PRINCIPLE 1: The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it. MORE LATER...

One of those classics , which never age. First published in 1936 , still very relevant . This book teaches you how, when interacting with people, you should think less about "me, me, me", and try and focus more on the other person. This is something that I forget most of the times, and this book taught me to be a little bit more considerate about the other person's thoughts, judge less, and, most importantly, admit more that even if I'm right, this doesn't make the other person be wrong.It's mostly a book that teaches about tolerance, diplomacy and being friendly, suggests that you give more honest compliments, smile more often and have more empathy towards others. I saved lots of notes from this book, and I will surely go back to read them again from time to time.
