Part One : Fundamental Techniques in Handling PeopleChapters1. Don't criticize, condemn or complain.2. Give honest and sincere appreciation.3. Arouse in the other person an eager want.Principles1. "If You Want to Gather Honey, Don't Kick Over the Beehive"2. The Big Secret of Dealing with People3. "He Who Can Do This Has the Whole World with Him. He Who Cannot Walks a Lonely Way"Part Two: Six ways to make people like youChapters1. Become genuinely interested in other people.2. Smile.3. Remember that a person's name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language.4. Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves.5. Talk in terms of the other person's interests.6. Make the other person feel important - and do it sincerely.Principles1. Do This and You'll Be Welcome Anywhere2. A Simple Way to Make a Good First Impression3. If You Don't Do This. You Are Headed for Trouble4. An Easy Way to Become a Good Conversationalist5. How to Interest People6. How to Make People Like You InstantlyPart Three: Win people to your way of thinkingChapters1. The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.2. Show respect for the other person's opinions. Never say, "You're wrong."3. If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically.4. Begin in a friendly way.5. Get the other person saying "yes, yes" immediately.6. Let the other person do a great deal of the talking.7. Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers.8. Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view.9. Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires.10. Appeal to the nobler motives.11. Dramatize your ideas.12. Throw down a challenge.Principles1. You Can't Win an Argument2. A Sure Way of Making Enemies — And How to Avoid It3. If You're Wrong, Admit It4. A Drop of Honey5. The Secret of Socrates6. The Safety Valve in Handling Complaints7. How to Get Cooperation8. A Formula That Will Work Wonders for You9. What Everybody Wants10. An Appeal That Everybody Likes11. The Movies Do It. TV Does It. Why Don't You Do It?12. When Nothing Else Works, Try ThisPart Four: Be a Leader: How to Change People Without Giving Offense or Arousing ResentmentChaptersA leader's job often includes changing your people's attitudes and behavior. Some suggestions to accomplish this:1. Begin with praise and honest appreciation.2. Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly.3. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.4. Ask questions instead of giving direct orders.5. Let the other person save face.6. Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement. Be "hearty in your approbation and lavish in your praise."7. Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to.8. Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct.9. Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest.Principles1. If You Must Find Fault, This Is the Way to Begin2. How to Criticize — And Not Be Hated for It3. Talk About Your Own Mistakes First4. No One Likes to Take Orders5. Let the Other Person Save Face6. How to Spur People On to Success7. Give a Dog a Good Name8. Make the Fault Seem Easy to Correct9. Making People Glad to Do What You Want

Some of the advice in this book is ageless. The application of its use should be specific and this book doesn't really afford insights into that aspect. Social Intelligence.. still looking for a good book on that one.

This book surprised the hell out of me. I thought I would hate it, I really dislike "self-help" books. There were a lot of "duh" types of tips, but a lot of the advice given were things I had never thought of before, at least in the way he suggested. Definitely something everyone should read.

I've heard of the book for a very long time, but I hate things hyped by everyone, so I didn't read it when it was published in my country. I also thought that the title was so cheap and this book just contained tricks to deal with people and "win" them. I have to admit I was wrong. This book summed up the most basic rule in human relationship: you have to treat people with sincerity, and you have to have genuine interest in people. The techniques in this book will not work without that as a base. I really like it, and I learned one thing or two from the book. However I still think that there are bitches which you cannot "win" or "influence". They just deserve your slaps.
Awesome book with really relevant principles for today's "me first" world.

HOW TO WIN FRIENDS AND INFLUENCE PEOPLE???Based on my personality I don't have the ability to persuade people. Most of the time I want to spend my time alone rather than to spend it with others. Even if i'm introvert by nature doesn't mean I can survive without people. God said "It's not good for a man to be alone" and "No man is an island" according to the English poet John Donne. We can't achieve success and solve our problems alone. Revealing our feeling is the beginning of healing.Winning friends and influencing people is indeed a very tough work. You can't do it in just a snap. I believe that we can't make everybody love us. There's always a so called basher or a hater in our lives. Bill Cosby quoted "I don't know the key to success but the key to failure is trying to please everyone." Attracting people can be done usually by a famous celebrity, politician, or if you're working in sales or any business related jobs.The bible says ".....Our purpose is to please God, not people. He alone examines the motives of our hearts" (1 Thessalonians 2:4). Even if there'll be times in our lives that we should please people for a certain reason we must not be gone astray from the real purpose. Once we put our security to God, our relationship with people will put into a perspective. We'll learn the counter-cultural way of loving our neighbors as ourselves. We'll learn how to treat others with selfless love, dignity, and respect regardless of how we feel. So in case you win a friend or influence a person, it's not because of you alone but because of God's intervention and purpose. Because you decided to please God in every area of your life, you'll be used as an influence to share the message of God's love and salvation to others through your words and actions. This is a reminder to each and everyone of us.

Although I was very sceptical of the title of this book, this very soon changed when I started reading it. It is exceptionally "hands-on", and you can start using what he writes immediately. It really is a "dummies" guide for how to get along with people. Following his advice (read every chapter twice, make notes...) allow for better remembering his many tips. I already recommended it to a number of people.

When I first saw the title of this book I thought it to be a rather manipulative-sounding title. But when I opened the pages and began to partake in these common knowledge, but not commonly practiced, principles... I became very enthralled and enlightened. The only thing that I have against this book is that once each principle is laid out and a few examples are given, there really is no need to drag out the point for another couple of pages or so. This book has changed the way I perceive people, the way they act, and the things they say. We all want to find approval and all want to feel important. That's what this book is about, not winning or influencing, but genuinely caring about the needs of others. Having a servant's heart.

This is one book that I re-read every other year. It contains practical advice when dealing with people, along with inspirational anecdotes and quotes that drive home the points the author is trying to make.

Este libro, en un comienzo, me pareció fantasioso e incluso peligroso, comenzando por el título, que parecía casi digno de serial killer (qué miedo que alguien lea cómo influenciar a los demás). Sin embargo, la curiosidad y el hecho de que sea un texto ícono, recomendado en tantas listas de clásicos, me hizo intentarlo de todas formas.Me alegro de ello, porque resulta que lo encontré BUENÍSIMO. Me enterneció y me hizo reír, y es que vi a tantas personas conocidas en sus relatos. También a mí misma. Me causó tanta gracia, y además está tan bien escrito. No solo aprendí, sino que también lo disfruté. Me hizo sentir simpatía por todo el género humano y con la simpatía... bueno, con la simpatía se logra todo.Creo que es un libro amable y, aunque algunos ejemplos lleguen a ser sospechosos... me lo creí. Tiene sentido. No opino, como dicen otras críticas, que sea un texto meramente complaciente y zalamero, sobre cómo caer bien mintiendo... en vez, siento que es un tratado acertado sobre los beneficios de saber escuchar, y las consecuencias de tratar a la gente con amor, y también a uno mismo. El amor hace florecer todo, incluso a las personas. Hace que uno quiera cooperar, en vez de oponerse. Hace que todos brillemos, tanto los que dan la mano, como los que la toman, cuando recordamos que somos un equipo.En fin, que me encantó. A poner sus ideas en práctica. Solo le pongo cuatro estrellas porque tanto ejemplo, a veces me hacía sentir que estaba en un curso de cómo vender por teléfono o algo así, jajaja. Pero tal vez más adelante le ponga cinco. Primero tengo que digerirlo.

from this book we learn many of self control and understanding others

A little hokey in parts, but overall a good, practical, albeit somewhat obvious guide for dealing successfully with people. Sometimes it paints a rather bleak and narcissistic picture of the human race, but I can't say that's terribly incorrect! Basically, be kind, be humble and recognize that everyone desperately wants to be significant and live a life of meaning. Helping others feel that way is the quickest way to connect with them and help you accomplish your objectives. It sounds cold and self-serving, but I don't get the sense Carnegie means anything other than how to connect sincerely with others and suceed -- after all, he's giving people career advice. It's worth a read, especially as a classic of the self-help genre.

Overall I think this is a really useful book which I would recommend to anyone. However, I think it's important to understand that this is way of initially starting relationships. These tactics are not sustainable long-term. One thing that the book supports but doesn't clearly point out is that people are drawn to those who seem to care about them. It points out the ways which we might not notice that tell people we care about them.
This book taught me to see things from the perspective of others and take accountability for my own successes and failures.

A great book recommended by my father and I really found this book really useful in terms of dealing with people in general and as the title suggests wining friends A great book that I recommend to anyone the only problem that I see with this book is that it is a bit outdated but at the same time way ahead of its time

It seems I would see references to this book everywhere I turned, so I decided to read it. It's got great content and gives some really good advice about how to handle relationships with people. Some of the concepts were pretty obvious but it doesn't hurt to go over common courtesy. I found it had a lot of topics and advice that has helped me personally more than it has with my relationships. Regardless, this is a book everyone should read.
Good book to enjoy reading.
I'm sure this will not be the last time I read this book. An excellent summary of techniques in leadership that I'm sure will be useful into the future.

The first half of this book was far more interesting to me than the second, mainly because I'm not currently in any sort of position of authority, but it was all great information for in introvert such as me. We shall see in the coming weeks just how big of an impact it had on me, but I'm hoping I can keep many of the things listed in mind when dealing with others, as it not only seems like it will improve my social life (providing it works well), but will make me feel better about the person I am.

I'm giving it 4 stars because of the importance of the book. If everyone applied even just a few points from it, life in general would be a lot more enjoyable. That being said, about 80% of the book is anecdotal and at times, reading another story about someone improving something at their workplace gets a bit tedious. A lot of the points made in the book aren't ground-breaking and you're unlikely to discover something you've never heard before, but the points still merit mention since so few people regularly apply them. I'd give it 3 stars but the extra star will give it more visibility. Worth going through at least once.
A very nice book that portrays the human psyche and how to get into the good books of others. A great read for understanding people and developing relationships.

It is a very useful and iluminating book. It is not boring at all but on the contrary, Dale Carnagie made it enjoyable and easy to read. Definitely one book I recommend to everyone who would like to be a little better himself.

This book is a must read for everyone especially those who are in roles of leadership! There is a time and place for everything. Just because you are right, you still might be wrong... Read this book!
Very enlightening. Shows specific things to be nice to people and have them like you back. Also attributes you need to be a successful leader.

A great book that helps the reader understand key actions to connect, understand and influence people. The important thing to remember throughout this book however, is that our intentions and actions should be genuine. Without that, we run the risk of being seen as a manipulator and lose sight of the entire purpose of speaking with people and motivating action.I also enjoyed reading this book because it presented information through the actions of different characters we have all heard about, such as the past US presidents, inventors, philosophers etc. Dale Carnegie has done a great job in writing this book, since I have found some of the methods mentioned to be effective in my daily life.

The title might be somewhat off-putting, and some of my friends were confused, saying "but you HAVE friends". But the book is full of insights concerning relationships and human engineering, all backed by good examples, and gave me a much better perspective on how to handle important interactions. It's mainly applicable in a professional field (business relationships), but can also be good for relationships with family and friends, I think, taken with a grain of salt. I'd probably recommend this to anyone.
this book is interesting for anyone who learn about skill with peoplethe way to tell us by people's story

Great book, terrible title!The title of this book seems to imply that this book will teach you how to manipulate people into doing what you want. What it really discusses is how to conduct meaningful interactions with others, by treating others with the same integrity and respect that we all would like in return. It is the mother of all self help books and you will find that Covey echos many of the concepts discussed in this book.

A well written book with great examples of men in the past. This book should be read by all the mangers because it does tell how bad a manager can get if you don't follow some of the basic principles in life of smiling and listening. Recommended for all ages. Don't be a talker and if you want to be one then make sure the other person is a good listener :-)

I listened to the audio version, which made the book seem reaaaaaaaaaaallllllllllllly slow, but not boring. Most of the book was examples of how Dale's approach works, and how to get what you want while not making the other person feel slighted.Like most old books, I had to force myself to not roll my eyes at the clichéd mentions, knowing that this book IS the original.Certainly a worthy read, if only to remind you to slow the hell down and think about how you're treating people.

The author has a great understanding about human nature. He help us to understand how to dealing with people and make them important and feel appreciated. He also help us to handling with other without making them manipulated. These book is rich of relationship solution!

Great, great book! The concepts can be applied to parenting, teaching, business, basically anywhere in life. I think this should be required reading in college! It's just the basics of how to work with people...we forget how important the little things are.
A well written book. Enjoyed reading it...
Very interesting stuff!

Although this book has a lot of common sense in it, it support its points with anecdotal evidence that comes across as being genuine. The mix of lesson and story made it very effective in showing how to implant the discussed techniques. I enjoyed it and was glad to have read it.
Great practical guidelines for each of us in developing human relations.
A classic book that has already made its mark. But for the modern day, How to Talk to Anyone by Leil Lowndes is a formidable supplement.

Fabulous book that made me realize everything I did wrong with my relationships, especially in graduate school. But there were a few affirming moments when I realized what I have been doing well in my life. This book is geared for those in business but everyone should read it, as it is about basic principles of human interaction. Up sides are that it is pro-human relations and makes you want to improve yourself. It also has tons of historical and interesting stories. Down side is the obviously sexist time it was printed and many statements are offensive to modern women.

It was a fun book to read. Most of what is written in it is common sense, but it nice to have someone point it out to you with a story to remember it. What's actually totally awesome, is that the book is so old that a lot of examples are old gangsters and mafiosos. Everything is awesome !!

I had the pleasure of listening to How to Win Friends as an audiobook on my commute to work. It's a classic for a reason - full of common sense advice (the type we're prone to forget) and charming anecdotes from the early 20th century that fortunately have never been updated, providing a very interesting view into the professional and personal lives of folks in the 1920s and 1930s. The principles in the book, like most good advice, are easy to understand but harder to enact consistently. I found myself wanting to strive for them, though - and that made this book worth it for me.

I read this book while waiting in a really long line at the DMV more than a decade ago. Although I didn't really learn anything new because most of the stuff that Dale Carnegie brings up on here have already been pretty much taught to me by my wiser elders while growing up, I still value this book and give a copy of it as a gift every now and then, especially to those who seem to need it.One of the best parts that I remember from this book is the following passage: "If some people are so hungry for a feeling of importance that they eventually go insane to get it, imagine what miracle you and I can achieve by giving people honest appreciation this side of insanity."I couldn't have said it better myself!

This was a really good book. The information in it is practical and simple. A lot of self-help/self-improvement texts seem to be a little "preachy" and superior, this isn't.This is a worthwhile read for anyone interested in improving their interpersonal skills and understanding of social dynamics.
This is a starter. Don't settle on this book. Also, it's often misunderstood by young minds.

From when I heard about this book, I felt as if it was necessary for me to read, for future experience, and as I started reading it, I learned many ways to gain friends and repect from others. Although, the ways are not only listed, but are proved by quotes, the author's experience, and real historical events.  After you read this book, you get more cautious of your actions, and you also are able to catch a mistake you might do before even doing it, which, obviously will make you a better person, and improve your manners.  The reason for giving it a four star rating is that it made me feel like reading a history book, which of course isn't that exciting. The writer proves his point in many ways when only one can be sufficient for the readers to agreewith his objective, but other than that, I find this book a great key for improving yourself, as it gives you amazing techniques in handling people, and others for making people like you. I think that the techniques and advices given, are everlasting, because this book covers human nature. Also, some proof for this point of view is that the author mentioned many historical events where these suggestions were applied, and are still affectionated at the time.

Absolutely fantastic read.This book covers basic principles in human relations and how to apply them to everyday life. I found this book not only inspiring but easy to follow and implement changes in the way I relate to people I meet everyday.

I can see why this has remained such a timeless classic in everything from business to sales. The concepts are all rather simple, but the author, through each revision, manages to present such a crackling, quick moving lesson that one if forced to agree and attempt to change accordingly. [return][return]I read this again in conjunction with the Carnegie Immersion course. Anyone would benefit from both. There are a lot of fine take-aways I could cite here but the main point is probably to practice it.

I wish I had read this when I was 15 instead of 33. Time will tell if it helps me any, but I believe with conscious effort, the lessons in this timeless classic will ultimately be to my advantage as an adult. We'll see...

Apparently I've been taught most of these principles thorughout my life - they all seemed like common sense to me and things that I thought all people already knew. That's not to say that I'm doing all of these things or that I'm great at some of these things, but they are certainly things that I've been taught and strived for my entire life. I'd like to get an actual copy of this book as I was just listening the audio version and so it would be good to be able to mark parts of this up and review it in more depth.
A classic. I read it in junior high and picked it up again a few years ago. It is a classic and one that I read again from time to time.
Dale Carnegie was alive nearly 3 generation before me!! but his writings follow the world order forever...

Chock-full of stuff I highlighted, this was an easy, interesting read. Just like any other "social psych" book, many of the principles/lessons are obvious but it's not till you see it on paper that you realise it's something that you should be doing because it makes so much sense.I wish I had read it earlier. Who knows how useful it would have been in.. life? Haha. But anyways, better late than never and I'm glad to have read it only now because then I can match it to the people and examples I see at work. There is more context and I better appreciate the examples he has listed. In any case, it's one of those books worth a re-read every once in a while.
This book is good because it gives clear frameworks to follow in good times and in bad when dealing with people. It isn't just theoretical. The stories are great as well.
It gives you the right advice. It's just how the advice is put into action.

link to original postThis book has been popular for a long while now. And because it is so well written, I gave it 2 out of 5 stars. My problem is that everything in this book is pretty much common sense, and, if anything, I was saddened that society needs self-improvement books like this in the first place. In all honesty, if you think you need this book, what you really need is a kick in the behind and a reality check. Look inside yourself and you ca save money on buying this book. Such a disappointment as I heard so many great things about this book.
Great to finally finish this book! Although quite a few of the stories are dated, this book is full of sound advice.

None of the concepts were completely new to me but the anecdotal examples were very beneficial to see how the concepts were put to use in real life scenarios. I felt some of the material was dated since it was written in the 30s but many of the principles still apply today. I would love to read an updated version of the book that takes into account technology, the credit card culture, online dating and social media. I also hated how simplistic and naive the section on mental illness was and would be fine if they deleted that section. Overall it was a very good book with good tips and techniques for how to present yourself and converse well with others.

This book describes how to communicate effectively. The methods described are useful and will surely get you benefits.It actually provokes you to think before speaking. In my opinion if you approach these methods eventually you will reap the benefits. You should read it once for sure.
Very implementable in daily lifes
A book everyone should not only read, but implement into their lives.
Easy and entertaining read with lots if value. Looking forward to reviewing it periodically going forward.
As a matter of fact i think its a very good one, But i think it was more useful in the past than now, People has changed now .A worthy book to read though.

I am really, really anti self-help books, but when I was out of things to read, I found this on a shelf at home, and thought "ah, let's see what these self-righteous people have to say". But when I read it, I really liked it. On the most part, I can say it was intuitive to me, because I've always had a sense of self when dealing with others. But the book helps point out dealing-with-people skills in a very well organized manner, and through very interesting historical anecdotes. It's a great feel for social skills and I thoroughly enjoyed it.
It has been awhile since I read this book but it was good.

Don't be put off by the slightly Machiavellian title. This book is about making the most of your interactions with others. It has lots of great tips about dealing with complaints, handling arguments and the best way to give somebody criticism.

Mommy made me read this when I was really young, primary school I think (evident lack of tactfulness on my side maybe? haha). Anyway this is one of the non-fiction staples. It is very to the point, convincing and effective.

Brilliant.Carnegie eloquently and vividly shows us how flawed we are as humans, but also shines a direct spotlight on how easily rectifiable our imperfections can be. Though his examples verge towards unrealistic fiction at times, he shows his true skills as a storyteller when sharing these small anecdotes with us. "How to Win Friends and Influence People" is an easy read which should be considered by all - businessperson or not - as there's great value in learning how to be kind, genuine, empathetic human beings.
Nice read, useful stuff, clear, precise presentation.
I felt so strongly that everyone should read this book that I let a friend -- ex-work husband Tim -- borrow this book. Yeah, he never returned it. It's a quick read.
The book tells you how to correct things that the most of the people are exercising.
A well written book. Enjoyed reading it...
I picked this up 20 years ago and I still read it every year, time to buy a copy. The zest you need, when feeling tired, old, stale and in need of a boost.
A should-read book on improving your business communication skills.

Following the instructions in the on how to get the most out of this book, I read each chapter then re-read it before proceeding. I was also attending an NLP Practitioner’s Course, reading the chapters on the bus to and from the venue. It is surprising how much the learnings of each overlapped.Yet what surprised me more was the examples of people who knew these principles yet failed to stick with them.So I became more acutely aware of my own need to practice the examples given in this book if I was to really benefit from it and build up my own consistency.In some ways it is remarkable that one book could contain so much and yet people write their own lesser versions. However, I now realize this is their own practice “in the world” of the principles put forth by Dale Carnegie. Rather than write a whole book, we tend now to write a variety of articles which play out the principles in different situations. Some people then gather them together into a book. But essentially Dale Carnegie’s version differs because it was his own central storage of his own learning and practice. He constantly revised and improved it and kept it as a live project, rather than a completed collection.This approach is that of the Mechanic profile in Talent Dynamics. Beginning with a systematic approach to situations and constantly revising and improving them. Even though Carnegie was dealing with people, he was doing so with a very deliberate task and purpose in mind. His teaching of people was almost a secondary benefit in his own mind to the system he was developing for himself to improve his own skills. The people he taught were part of his feedback to test his own competency.It is the level to which Dale Carnegie took these practices and applied them which has made his book such a classic for anyone to learn from over time. Read the more modern versions, but go back to this master as well.
Common sense advice from the pioneer of self-help. I would recommend to anyone.
I am re-reading this.

Basically, a good read, and with the over lying message that you need to pay attention to others emotional needs, be interested in them, and that will lead them to have positive feelings towards you. Not revelationary but it's a good dig in the ribs that we must take time to listen and take genuine interest in others.

My dad recommended this book. I was skeptical at first and read it halfheartedly. But then, I stumbled upon a line I read in this book, "I had the blues because I had no shoes until upon the street, I met a man who had no feet". Then I was hooked. Nuff said.
Another great motivational book!! Beeing in Business this book really spoke to me about customer service and like the Title sais influence people.
A book that changed the way I interpreted life.

This book is a great reminder on how we should act. The whole book can basically be summarised as "be nice to other people and try to put yourself in their shoes". It was first published in 1936 but (most of it) is still very relevant today. There were some good examples of the techniques working and I believe the world would be a better place if people took the advice.The final section on marriage advice was probably relevant to the time, but now appears very dated. It assumes that men and women have pre-defined roles where men go out and work whilst women stay home and cook and clean. His advice is still good, but the gender components should be ignored, as it goes both ways.This book is a good reminder as to how to behave. However, if you're using it as steps to get your own way then it won't work and you've completely missed the point. It is all about sincerity. Carnegie points this out in the final line of the Letters section when he states, "the principles taught in this book will work only when they come from the heart. I am not advocating a bag of tricks. I am talking about a new way of life."

كتاب ممتاز .. وناجم عن دراسات وخبرات ومشاهدات صادقة وواقعيةوبالفعل .. بمجرد قراءته وجدت نفسي أطبق أو على الأقل أقارن وألاحظ ما قرأته في الكتاب على الواقع .. نعم .. نصائحه وملاحظاته صحيحة بالتأكيدوكان هذا الكتاب من الكتب التي أثرت في تكوين شخصيتي كثيرا حيث قرأته في مراهقتي في أهم فترة لتشكيل معالم الشخصية والفكر بعد الطفولةكتاب رائع ولا شك

There is a reason that this book has been so well known for so many years. I learned many things regarding interacting with people. I learned about how to develop relationships with people as well as some of the common pitfalls to avoid that can destroy those relationships.
The book I have is not on Good Reads. I have a 1967 edition. Very sweet book. I loved it!!!
This is a must have on the bookshelf. I find it a bit much to read in one hit.It is one of those books you read as you need to read it - that way it sinks in better and works for what you need now.

I really enjoyed this book. As usual Mr.Carnegie using great tone and amazing analogies to get their point across. This book is not about getting friends. It's about understanding the different personalities and thought processes of the people around you.Great read.

very important to read

Awesome !!!

In this book the author illustrates different principles which can help to improve and be a better person, citing examples of many great people in history. The book is slow but the author has done a great job in expressing his ideas.One of the quote which I will always remember is "Judge not, that ye be not judged".

We live in a hasty society where we do not really listen to each other anymore. We tend to bluff and only show our superficial façade that we generated throughout the years. In negotiations we want to win whatever is at stake and in times of social networking we know more people than ever before but paradoxically we are growing more socially isolated. With this book Dale Carnegie shows us that we need to connect more to one another. He displays all the essential social skills to establish and cement good relationships, whether they are private or professional. Friendliness, listening, empathy, constructive feedback and smiling are just a few of his tips and tricks to win friends and influence people. So if you would like to read the nice stories that he uses to clarify his theory and you would like to upgrade your people skills that will make you stand out even more in a crowd, I am glad to recommend you this book.
Great book about interacting with people. i thought it would be about manipulation, and was wary, but it turned out to be great.

This book was a fairly interesting read, albeit a little conflictive for my inner peace. On the one hand, I think a lot of tips suggested make a superficial person. They stray away from the natural response to situations of a person, to a place eerily close to what we call a people pleaser. On the other hand, it mentions time and again to be sincere and honest with how we deal with people, or else to risk being tagged as pretentious. I guess it all depends in what way one utilises the tips mentioned in the book. One needs to be cautious and careful with this book. Also, I recommend leaving out close friends and relatives with the methods of handling people mentioned in this book, unless absolutely necessary. You'll know you have a great friend if you never need to consult this book because of them.

When I saw this book title in my senior book shelf, I felt the content of the book would be flattering. When I read this book recently I felt regret for having bad feeling in the past. Dale explained how to deal each and every aspect of life which we don't even know how it effects. No matter what profession is, you always so many principles in this book which you can apply to any situation in your life.

It took me about 7 months to get through this book. This is not one you read over a weekend for something to do. It is very poignant and if you apply the lessons learned they will take you a long way. I am also partial to such methods as the Sandler system, but this looks at influence and leadership in a slightly different way and is just as valid. This is a book you take notes with, highlight passages, underline paragraphs, mark up...it should look like a school textbook when you are done with it. Although it was written some 80 years ago, the lessons to be learned form this are timeless.

Believe the hype. This book is great. A lot of people seem to think that this book teaches you how to manipulate people, but if they think that they probably haven't read it. One of the key points of the book is that none of these strategies will work unless you genuinely care about other people, and you want what's best for them. If you have only your best interests in mind, then almost everyone will sense you are insincere and you will fail to achieve genuine influence on all but the most desperate people.
A classic. Although some of the terminology is a little outdated.

Like other reviewers, I was surprised to find that I liked this book more than I expected. While it might not be the biggest page-turner ever written, many of the anecdotal examples are amusing and I think the advice could help people.

But for the most part it wasn"t and I really enjoyed this book. I discovered and started applying (sometimes rediscovered and reasserted efforts to apply) many true principles about how to get along with others mostly based on things like being considerate, respectful, kind, a good listener etc... Dale Carnegie’s famous, How To Win Friends and Influence People, also known as “The big secret to dealing with people”, is an eye opening book. Before reading this book, you would think you’ve been doing almost everything perfectly when it comes to handling people. It’ll make you think carefully about your actions and make you more self-conscious about what you say and how you treat other people. The purpose of this book is to help people maneuver their way through their different relationships, along with all of the people you come into contact with in a productive way. The book will make you think more about the other person’s perspective whenever you disagree with them. If you’re really genuine about learning how to deal with others, you’ll catch yourself being more aware of how you interact with people. Carnegie mentions that, “He who can do this has the world with him. He who cannot, walks a lonely way,” he is saying that if you can master the tips given to make people like you, winning people to your way of thinking and being a leader, you will have people in the palm of your hands.Carnegie showed no signs of favoritism and was fair throughout the whole book. He considered all point of views a person could possibly have in the different situations addressed in the book. He showed the adverse and typical ways of dealing with situations followed by a positive way to go about things in situations, which ties into one of the many lesson’s Carnegie touched on; don’t criticize, condemn, or complain. Carnegie says,” Instead of condemning people, let’s try to understand them. Try to figure out why they do what they do…This breeds sympathy, tolerance and kindness,” this quote is declaring is that people are going to do things that you don’t agree with, however you should always try to look at things from their point of view instead of being quick to judge or belittle. He gives an example from the life of Abraham Lincoln. Abraham Lincoln wrote an insulting letter in his town’s newspaper about another politician. Soon after, the politician found out Lincoln wrote the letter and challenged him to fight in the duel. Luckily, the duel was interrupted and stopped. After that incident, Lincoln never again wrote an insulting letter and he almost never criticized anybody for anything.Overall, the book was well written and organized. Carnegies’ points were straightforward and comprehensive. The points were simple and apparent, yet significant and commonly neglected. He also elaborated on each point and gave specific examples for each. For example, one of the points in the book was to be a good listener and encourage others to talk about themselves. That sounds simple, but people sometimes fail to realize how quick they are to talk about themselves while interacting with others. He also gave examples from the lives of well –known people, which made the book seem more realistic and relatable.Dale Carnegie wrote this book to help people become better at dealing with all types of people and looking at situations from the other person’s point of view. Through the story, he helps the readers to take a second look at how they treat people, and gives them helpful tips on how to improve their relationships with them.

The book shares very good insight into what should be done to build good relationship with people. 2 disadvantages which I did not enjoy: 1) real life examples of old times - you cannot change it, as the book was written 80 years ago, 2) high number of examples to prove the recommendation - I had to skip most of them as they were keeping from reading the book at pace.

A lot of it seems pretty common sense, but its filled with a lot of anecdotes and other examples that really flesh out the advice and make it insightful. I highlighted the heck out of it and i got yellow sticky tabs throughout the entire book, so hopefully I will someday put some of what I learned to good use. If you're at all interested in this sort of book, then it's probably a good find and will certainly help you.

“To be interesting, be interested.”The book I read was the revised 80s version. I didn’t know this until I started the book and then I didn’t want to change. Usually, I hate when books are updated. Leave it alone. If you think you have a lot of new ideas, just write a new book. Because between revising the book in the 80s and when it was originally written, it was 50 years, given that the book was written in the 30s. And I wanted to read the original original version.“A person’s toothache means more to that person than a famine in China which kills a million people. A boil on one’s neck interests one more than forty earthquakes in Africa. Think of that the next time you start a conversation.”Because the book, in what appears one of the first self-help book (in the sense of what we know today), is actually great. It is simple, basic, and true, and after 80 years, not much has been improved on, except today’s books make the author seem like some sort of douche. No how idea how current authors do that, but they all write self-help books that seem to have huge subtitles under each page that says, “I AM A DOUCHE”. But this book doesn’t have that.“Better give your path to a dog than be bitten by him in contesting for the right. Even killing the dog would not cure the bite.”I wouldn’t mind rereading the original book again. When reading it, at first I thought, I know all this, but after a while, I thought, I’m not really applying it as much as I want to. A good reminder on what parts I can use. Of course, no book is a blueprint and this one shouldn’t be either. I read reviews on this book from people who claimed it will turn you into a doormat. I think that’s where one has to be intelligent in reading self-help books. One uses the parts that one finds weakness in one’s natural personality, at the same time, building on one’s own unique skillset.And finally, some choice quotes from the book. These are not from the author, but quotes he uses from other famous people, so credit to his choice of quotes, not to his quotes,Publilius Syrus: “We are interested in others when they are interested in us."-Emerson: “Every man I meet is my superior in some way. In that, I learn of him.”-Disraeli: “Talk to people about themselves and they will listen for hours."-Galileo: "You cannot teach a man anything; you can only help him to find it within."-Lord Chesterfield (to his son): "Be wiser than other people if you can; but do not tell them so."-"In a similar way, General Robert E. Lee once spoke to the president of the Confederacy, Jefferson Davis, in the most glowing terms about a certain officer under his command. Another officer in attendance was astonished. “General,” he said, " do you not know that the man of whom you speak so highly is one of your bitterest enemies who misses no opportunity to malign you?” "Yes," replied General Lee, “but the president asked my opinion of him; he did not ask for his opinion of me.”"-"By the way, I am not revealing anything new in this chapter. Two thousand years ago, Jesus said: “Agree with thine adversary quickly.”"-"And 2,200 years before Christ was born, King Akhtoi of Egypt gave his son some shrewd advice - advice that is sorely needed today. “Be diplomatic,” counseled the King. “It will help you gain your point.”"-"The Chinese have a proverb pregnant with the age-old wisdom of the Orient: “He who treads softly goes far.”"
Great info!
A classic in human relationships. Learnt a fair bit, hope it stays with me.

The tips in this book are timeless. The style of speech and the examples, however, were not and might sound a little stilted to our 21st century ears. I would still encourage everyone to read it.Carnegie starts from first impressions and goes all the way through leadership. He explains how to get people to like you and how to get people to do what you need them to do. What he says here is still highly applicable to today's world--amazing, considered this was written in 1936. This is the classic business book for soft skills, and you can see how so many books that came after it can be seen as a variation on Carnegie's original themes. A must read for those who like business non-fiction. I did get the distinct impression that this might just be a long advertisement for the Carnegie classes, but that's all right.

Carnegie's book is pretty good advice if you want to work in business, especially in sales, as well as in other workplaces. The title for the book about 'friends' could be misleading for some people though as it is not really about making friends socially.
2nd time through it. Lots of good nuggets.

I should have read this book way earlier, as one thing is sure - it certainly made me/will make me a better person.The title is somewhat pretentious, but don't get fooled by it. The book is all about dealing with people in a good way. Treating them good and being full of understanding, no matter the situation. They will be happy and you will more likely benefit from it.I was not fond of the examples supporting his arguments, and on times, there were just so many of them, but other than that this book seemed like a helpful "manual". Being a good communicator is never out-of-date. I hope applying some of the advice, I will generally improve my communication skills and then start building my own success stories.
It was one of my pre-critical thinking books. It was a good read back then but I don't think I would be able to read it now.
I read this book in 1998 with a group from work. We would read a chapter a week, then watch part of a video series. All of us got promotions that year.
Greer classic, it becomes a bit redundant at one points but the message is clear and effective.

Excellent points in this book about how to manage people and your own manners. Get ready to be genuinely interested in other people, to put on good manners and to set down your own ego to make others feel special. Get ready to learn how to ignore the need for credibility and achieve progress instead by letting others get the ideas.This book will teach you to give space for others to become your friends and will encourage you to think in terms of other people's interests. There are also a LOT of interesting anecdotal stories, but you don't necessarily need to read all of them.One note: This is an old book and so has some pretty sexist statements for today's time about marriage. It assumes women are nagging (and gives no example of men nagging) and so adresses its chapter "don't nag" entirely to women, and also writes as though intellectual achievements are solely a male need. (In my short life I've definitely experienced nagging men. Probably more nagging women than men, but it's not as black and white as he portrays.) He even encourages women to lay down their own need to excel to stroke their husband's ego because he needs a calm house to come home to after a long day at work.Obviously we're a lot more diverse in our thinking today, know that both men and women have a need to excel and have their egos stroked.Ignoring that one chapter, which, in spite of a little bit of sexism, was still right that nagging is bad, this is an excellent book.

من الكتب اللي بعتبرها رسائل من ربنا الي :")مش عارفة الكاتب .. مش محددة كتاب .. بقلب في اللاب الاقيه ! من أكتر الكتب اللي اخدت فيها سكرين شوت و انا بقرأها :))كله رسائل كنت بستشعر انه بيكلمني أنا في كتير من الفقرات :))أدركت اني بتعامل بطريقة سيئة و ان أي حد بيحبني رغم معاملتي دي يستاهل جائزة الدولة التقديرية .. بس بما ان مفيش دولة .. فهكتفي بالدعاء لهم :"Dالكتاب قيم و اسلوبه بسيط و هدفه واضح :))

A 'classic' in the leadership genre, I expected a lot from this book and was only a little disappointed. The entirety of the book can more or less be summed up in the words "be selfless, and mindful of others". Many of the 'principles' were variations on a theme instead of being distinct leadership principles. All told, it is still a must for the readers of leadership/management genre.

One of those classics I've always heard about and wanted to read. Sometimes these types of books can get a little boring, but Carnegie uses plenty of examples and interesting stories to keep you interested.
Very insightful, still applicable today

This is a handbook about human relations.Each chapter explains a fundamental principle for building and maintaining a good relationship with others. Carnegie uses a great deal of short stories of successful people to illustrate these principles to show how they really work. I found many of the stories really inspiring, but some of them didn't seem very relevant.A lot of the principles in this book are principles we already know or have heard of. Honestly, I was hoping to read about techniques I've never heard of, but I felt like I was reading the obvious.On the other hand, it was silly of me not to expect "the obvious". We all already have an idea of what makes good and bad relationships, isn't it common sense? However, we often miss to see the obvious clearly, we don't give it too much thought, and we often forget to apply these obvious principles when the time comes to deal with people. Carnegie tries to make us see these principles in a clearer way and also the benefits their application can bring us.While some people might find some of the techniques manipulative or only helpful to build fake relationships based on personal interests, I shall argue that Carnegie emphasizes many times the sincerity one should have while putting those techniques into action. And truth is all relationships are based on some sort of interest. This book, more than anything, tries to form good habits in us and it serves as a reminder of how to deal with people in a successful way. You definitely won't be wasting your time if you choose to read it.

A book with contents both illuminating and comically obvious in hindsight. Despite its unfortunate marketable title, which suggests a duplicity that is the antithesis of the authors intent, this collection of personal and historical antidotes is a remarkably interesting book which ought to be requisite reading for any human being who plans on existing on a planet with other human beings. That's most of you. The book sums to the golden rule. However, if one would do unto others as he would want to have done to himself, it is important to know oneself, what one would want, and (by easy generalization) human nature in general. In this dual way, Carnegie informs us not only about others but about ourselves. Classic.

This is a very old book, but several of the tips contained in this book are very relevant even in today's world.This can help improving relationships, communication with colleagues and reduce friction arising from ego clashes at workplace.
This should be taught in schools.
Great resource for all in learning how to interact with other people
My version was a little older, but it provided many good tips on the art of communication.
Planning to reread It in English due to work reason.

This is a book that you can't simply read and then put down to never revisit. It is like the Art of War, you need to think about the ideas and how they could be applied and attempt to apply them. Sometimes the lessons are hidden in the subtext and at least for someone like me, it was difficult to parse out the meanings or what I was supposed to take from each chapter.It isn't that the book is obtuse. I think many normal people could take a lot out of it. I think people like me should study it and use it as a bible for how to interact with people. Treating people with respect should be simple, but the means and reasons are not. Interacting with people is often complex and while some people have an innate ability and charisma when interacting with people. Others are not so blessed.The concept described in the book should be simple, but reads like the Design of Things. The purpose is to go through what I'll describe as scenarios or examples where the concepts are applied and discussed. It is more like a workshop or classroom. If there was a teacher then the person would have given some idea as to the message of each chapter. You could or should come to some conclusion by thinking about each chapter. It is part of the reason that it is a book that may need to be reread time and time again.It is part of a collection on how to not be an asshole and how to handle people. People are complex or at least appear complex. Part of that is that the motivations are often not clear and this book serves to provide some clarity to what those motivations are.
This book is one of those books that everyone should have a copy of. The content may seem little repeating and obvious to some people, but I found this book to be a great piece to read.

Transformative book. If you seek self-improvement, shorten your want-to-read list and check out this classic first. I avoided it for over a decade, despite having majored in psychology, because I interpreted the title as suggesting it was a how-to on manipulating others and being false in the corporate world. But it is far from this. It teaches you to always put others first and effect change in others by first changing how you approach others (with humility, respect and close listening) and then guiding them to want to change to benefit themselves. This approach has been restated countless times in modern self-help books on marriage, parenting, business success, and negotiation, and is rooted in psychology research, spiritual teaching and the lives of great leaders. But instead of being lecturing and admonishing, Carnegie engages you with true stories that show the inspiration for and application of his techniques. And he puts you at ease by pointing out how far he has come from his early years, giving hope to even the most awkward or ill-spoken. Dale Carnegie might not seem the most compelling life coach for readers in a digital age, but his lessons, gathered from centuries of others' learning, prove to be surprisingly relevant and enduring. It's also interesting to learn the back stories of corporate titans and US presidents, humanizing them and putting their later successes in context. The lessons may be repetitive in the middle third of the book, but press on to the final section, where Carnegie teaches you how to deal with conflict. It's an issue I've long struggled with, but find much more easy to remedy than I'd ever imagined. It is possible to learn tact and diplomacy (well, I'm trying). This was a revelation to me, she with foot in mouth.

A breezy and useful book on improving human relationships. I think this book should be required reading for the U.S. Congress. The book is packed with anecdotes about famous and not-so-famous people (e.g., folks that took Carnegie's course) that illustrate how to make people like you, win them over to your way of thinking, and change them without arousing resentment. The tips are variations on these fundamental principles, which are themselves an expansion of the Golden Rule (keeping in mind that everyone wants to feel important):1. Don't criticise, condemn, or complain.2. Give honest and sincere appreciation.3. Arouse an eager want in the other person.

How to Win Friends & Influence People  is an insightful, practical, effective and enjoyable book that (I believe) can make a positive impact in everyone's daily life. Though all of the principles suggested in this book appear overly simplistic, in practice, it can be quite a challenge (as it is not the norm, in my opinion). I would recommend this book to anyone that has tried to change to their situation at work, at home, anywhere, with anyone and not been successful. The principles suggested in this book might be a refreshing change and ultimately, get you what you want.
Classic book that everyone should read.

Really good reminders about how to treat people. Carnegie describes most of "winning friends and influencing people" as treating them with kindness, respect and dignity. All the examples were so dated (the book was originally written in 1936) but that almost made the overarching principles ring more true.Favorite quotations:"Even in such technical lines as engineering, about 15 percent of one’s financial success is due to one’s technical knowledge and about 85 percent is due to skill in human engineering—to personality and the ability to lead people."I believe it!“The great aim of education,” said Herbert Spencer, “is not knowledge but action.”On the futility of criticism:"Criticism is futile because it puts a person on the defensive and usually makes him strive to justify himself. Criticism is dangerous, because it wounds a person’s precious pride, hurts his sense of importance, and arouses resentment.""Criticisms are like homing pigeons. They always return home. Let’s realize that the person we are going to correct and condemn will probably justify himself or herself, and condemn us in return."Lincoln on criticism:"One of his favorite quotations was “Judge not, that ye be not judged.” And when Mrs. Lincoln and others spoke harshly of the southern people, Lincoln replied: “Don’t criticize them; they are just what we would be under similar circumstances.”"Benjamin Franklin, tactless in his youth, became so diplomatic, so adroit at handling people, that he was made American Ambassador to France. The secret of his success? “I will speak ill of no man,” he said, “. . . and speak all the good I know of everybody.” Any fool can criticize, condemn and complain—and most fools do. But it takes character and self-control to be understanding and forgiving."On getting people to do what you want:"There is only one way under high heaven to get anybody to do anything. Did you ever stop to think of that? Yes, just one way. And that is by making the other person want to do it. Remember, there is no other way."“I consider my ability to arouse enthusiasm among my people,” said Schwab, “the greatest asset I possess, and the way to develop the best that is in a person is by appreciation and encouragement. “There is nothing else that so kills the ambitions of a person as criticisms from superiors. I never criticize anyone. I believe in giving a person incentive to work. So I am anxious to praise but loath to find fault. If I like anything, I am hearty in my approbation and lavish in my praise.“In my wide association in life, meeting with many and great people in various parts of the world,” Schwab declared, “I have yet to find the person, however great or exalted his station, who did not do better work and put forth greater effort under a spirit of approval than he would ever do under a spirit of criticism.”"Tomorrow you may want to persuade somebody to do something. Before you speak, pause and ask yourself: “How can I make this person want to do it?”"If out of reading this book you get just one thing—an increased tendency to think always in terms of other people’s point of view, and see things from their angle—if you get that one thing out of this book, it may easily prove to be one of the building blocks of your career."On making friends:"If we want to make friends, let’s put ourselves out to do things for other people—things that require time, energy, unselfishness and thoughtfulness."***"People rarely succeed at anything unless they have fun doing it."Importance of names:"We should be aware of the magic contained in a name and realize that this single item is wholly and completely owned by the person with whom we are dealing . . . and nobody else. The name sets the individual apart; it makes him or her unique among all others. The information we are imparting or the request we are making takes on a special importance when we approach the situation with the name of the individual. From the waitress to the senior executive, the name will work magic as we deal with others.Having good conversations:"So if you aspire to be a good conversationalist, be an attentive listener. To be interesting, be interested. Ask questions that other persons will enjoy answering. Encourage them to talk about themselves and their accomplishments. Remember that the people you are talking to are a hundred times more interested in themselves and their wants and problems than they are in you and your problems.""There is one all-important law of human conduct. If we obey that law, we shall almost never get into trouble. In fact, that law, if obeyed, will bring us countless friends and constant happiness. But the very instant we break the law, we shall get into endless trouble. The law is this: Always make the other person feel important. John Dewey, as we have already noted, said that the desire to be important is the deepest urge in human nature; and William James said: “The deepest principle in human nature is the craving to be appreciated.” As I have already pointed out, it is this urge that differentiates us from the animals. It is this urge that has been responsible for civilization itself.""The unvarnished truth is that almost all the people you meet feel themselves superior to you in some way, and a sure way to their hearts is to let them realize in some subtle way that you recognize their importance, and recognize it sincerely. Remember what Emerson said: “Every man I meet is my superior in some way. In that, I learn of him.”On changing minds:"If a person makes a statement that you think is wrong—yes, even that you know is wrong—isn’t it better to begin by saying: “Well, now, look. I thought otherwise, but I may be wrong. I frequently am. And if I am wrong, I want to be put right. Let’s examine the facts.” There’s magic, positive magic, in such phrases as: “I may be wrong. I frequently am. Let’s examine the facts.”"We sometimes find ourselves changing our minds without any resistance or heavy emotion, but if we are told we are wrong, we resent the imputation and harden our hearts. We are incredibly heedless in the formation of our beliefs, but find ourselves filled with an illicit passion for them when anyone proposes to rob us of their companionship. It is obviously not the ideas themselves that are dear to us, but our self-esteem which is threatened. . . . The little word “my” is the most important one in human affairs, and properly to reckon with it is the beginning of wisdom. It has the same force whether it is “my” dinner, “my” dog, and “my” house, or “my” father, “my” country, and “my” God.""Any fool can try to defend his or her mistakes—and most fools do—but it raises one above the herd and gives one a feeling of nobility and exultation to admit one’s mistakes.""When we are right, let’s try to win people gently and tactfully to our way of thinking, and when we are wrong—and that will be surprisingly often, if we are honest with ourselves—let’s admit our mistakes quickly and with enthusiasm. Not only will that technique produce astonishing results; but, believe it or not, it is a lot more fun, under the circumstances, than trying to defend oneself. Remember the old proverb: “By fighting you never get enough, but by yielding you get more than you expected.”"In talking with people, don’t begin by discussing the things on which you differ. Begin by emphasizing—and keep on emphasizing—the things on which you agree. Keep emphasizing, if possible, that you are both striving for the same end and that your only difference is one of method and not of purpose. Get the other person saying “Yes, yes” at the outset. Keep your opponent, if possible, from saying “No.”"Wouldn’t you like to have a magic phrase that would stop arguments, eliminate ill feeling, create good will, and make the other person listen attentively? Yes? All right. Here it is: “I don’t blame you one iota for feeling as you do. If I were you I would undoubtedly feel just as you do.”On sympathy::Dr. Arthur I. Gates said in his splendid book Educational Psychology: “Sympathy the human species universally craves. The child eagerly displays his injury; or even inflicts a cut or bruise in order to reap abundant sympathy. For the same purpose adults . . . show their bruises, relate their accidents, illness, especially details of surgical operations. ‘Self-pity’ for misfortunes real or imaginary is, in some measure, practically a universal practice.”On showmanship:"This is the day of dramatization. Merely stating a truth isn’t enough. The truth has to be made vivid, interesting, dramatic. You have to use showmanship. The movies do it. Television does it. And you will have to do it if you want attention."And this was 1936!"It is always easier to listen to unpleasant things after we have heard some praise of our good points.""Asking questions not only makes an order more palatable; it often stimulates the creativity of the persons whom you ask. People are more likely to accept an order if they have had a part in the decision that caused the order to be issued.""Let us praise even the slightest improvement. That inspires the other person to keep on improving.""“Praise is like sunlight to the warm human spirit; we cannot flower and grow without it. And yet, while most of us are only too ready to apply to others the cold wind of criticism, we are somehow reluctant to give our fellow the warm sunshine of praise.”"one of the important rules of human relations: Always make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest."FUNDAMENTAL TECHNIQUES IN HANDLING PEOPLEPRINCIPLE 1Don’t criticize, condemn or complain. PRINCIPLE 2 Give honest and sincere appreciation. PRINCIPLE 3 Arouse in the other person an eager want.SIX WAYS TO MAKE PEOPLE LIKE YOUPRINCIPLE 1 Become genuinely interested in other people. PRINCIPLE 2 Smile.PRINCIPLE 3 Remember that a person’s name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language. PRINCIPLE 4 Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves. PRINCIPLE 5 Talk in terms of the other person’s interests. PRINCIPLE 6 Make the other person feel important—and do it sincerely.WIN PEOPLE TO YOUR WAY OF THINKINGPRINCIPLE 1 The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it. PRINCIPLE 2 Show respect for the other person’s opinions. Never say, “You’re wrong.” PRINCIPLE 3 If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically. PRINCIPLE 4 Begin in a friendly way. PRINCIPLE 5 Get the other person saying “yes, yes” immediately. PRINCIPLE 6 Let the other person do a great deal of the talking. PRINCIPLE 7 Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers. PRINCIPLE 8 Try honestly to see things from the other person’s point of view. PRINCIPLE 9 Be sympathetic with the other person’s ideas and desires. PRINCIPLE 10 Appeal to the nobler motives. PRINCIPLE 11 Dramatize your ideas. PRINCIPLE 12 Throw down a challenge.BE A LEADERPRINCIPLE 1 Begin with praise and honest appreciation. PRINCIPLE 2 Call attention to people’s mistakes indirectly. PRINCIPLE 3 Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person. PRINCIPLE 4 Ask questions instead of giving direct orders. PRINCIPLE 5 Let the other person save face. PRINCIPLE 6 Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement. Be “hearty in your approbation and lavish in your praise.” PRINCIPLE 7 Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to. PRINCIPLE 8 Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct. PRINCIPLE 9 Make the other person happy about doing the thing you suggest.

This book really opened my eyes to how people need each other in working relationships. The influence is not malicious that Carnegie speaks of, but more of a working influence. I can see how these skills can work in many relationships instead of being combative.
A surprisingly relevant book considering that it's 75 years old or whatever. Still plenty to learn, and a testament that human behavior doesn't change all that much over time.
I'm giving this four stars instead of 3 because I feel there are some good nuggets in there. However, I feel the book dragged on too much.

Lovely writing style, and the examples and illustrations show just how timeless this subject matter is.

Usually every good business book is also a good book on parenting. With that said, this is a great book on parenting... And business, marriage, church, and really any situation that involves interaction with other living creatures. It's nothing revolutionary in what it says, but it gives you subtle reminders to do the things you know you should be doing. I will criticize less, praise others more, empathize better, and respond with more tact after reading this book for the now second time through. It fits perfectly in the theme of books I've been reading lately which is social psychology.

This is the classic, and I finally got around to reading it. Good, down to earth advice, and helped along by some great stories. Easy to read and not to be missed.
It's a must read for some one looking to improve how to deal with people. Some examples on the book are exaggerated and does not sounds that real.
This is a great read and probably a should-read for most professionals.

There is no denying that the book contains truly remarkable advice which could not only help people to make friends and influence people, but also to make this a better place. But throughout the book, too much words and arguments are wasted on explaining specific ideas.

I have always liked Dale Carnegie's material. This one makes sense. Most people probably know most of the this stuff but just forget to use it. It's mostly about listening and respecting other people and show them you are truely interested in them, and not nodding just to "get it over with".

The thing that stuck with me after reading this book is how important it is to fully consider the people you are talking to. I had forgotten to care about other people. I have been trying to win friends by being impressive and interesting, but reading this book made me re-realize that the best way to get people to like you is to like them. Find them interesting. a really good summarisation of things to consider when dealing with people in personal and professional life. The anecdotes in the book are old but still quite relevant especially the ones quoted from a personal context.

Carnegie's book is a "must-read" for anyone working in business, dealing with people, or for those who simply want to become more adept at personal inter-relations. He writes in a very simple, easy to read style, and the book is replete with personal anecdotes which both emphasize his many points, while at the same time keeping the flow and pacing fresh, lively, and relevant. This is the kind of book you want to highlight, keep on your shelf, and refer back to frequently.

I feel this is a book for anyone wishing to have good communication skills. It has a lot of steps mentioned. It becomes difficult to remember so many steps. But it is revolving around some basic steps like appreciation, listening, courtesy and some more. It tells you to avoid criticism and pinpointing wrongdoings directly at maximum occasions. This is a must read for any sales and marketing person who wants to speak in terms of the buyer.
Filled with lots of interesting anecdotes, but nothing too ground-breaking. A must read for all Type A's out there ;)

I found this book very interesting and I enjoyed it more than I thought I would There are lots of tips that can be used today in both business and in ones personal life

A classic. Some recommendations seem very obvious, yet people still don't do them. A good read for those interested in personal communication, psychology, and business.

This book teaches you how, when interacting with people, you should think less about "me, me, me", and try and focus more on the other person. This is something that I forget most of the times, and this book taught me to be a little bit more considerate about the other person's thoughts, judge less, and, most importantly, admit more that even if I'm right, this doesn't make the other person be wrong.It's mostly a book that teaches about tolerance, diplomacy and being friendly, suggests that you give more honest compliments, smile more often and have more empathy towards others. I saved lots of notes from this book, and I will surely go back to read them again from time to time.

This is a manual on how to be a "people person". Reading it is like having a wise grandfather nudge you oh-so-gently into being a better and more pleasant human being. Carnegie's style is clear, conversational, and filled with anecdotes.
Lots of common sense. Most people would benefit from reading this. The basic message is this; be nice, and your life will work out a little better.

Finally read this classic! Its timeless wisdom is simply brilliant. Unsurprisingly, many professional development concepts have their roots in this work.

Classic for a reason. These are simple concepts that go a long way. The thinking behind Carnegie's work here may be hard for one to adjust to, but what you will find through the course of this text is that there is mileage left in kindness and sincere approbation. "Be lavish in your praise" and giving others the spotlight, to make another feel important, even for a few moments, listening emaptheically, is very often rewarded with surprising leaps in cooperation, sour grapes into sumptuous wine.

This classic has been on my To Read list for a long time. I was recently inspired to pick it up because of an article I read on Book Riot. A woman with Asperger’s wrote that this book was a life-changing tool for her, helping her understand people in a way that she struggled to do on her own. I found this book to be much more relevant than I expected from something written in the 1930s. Many are lessons I’ve picked up as I’ve matured, but it was cool to see it written here. I now wonder if I've indirectly learned from this source, considering how influential it is, nearly rising to the level of modern common sense. A lot of this advice will stick with me, when it comes to work and personal relationships.

I read this book as a freshman in high school and it really changed the way I look at life. Many of the suggestions come naturally to some people, but for me it was a real eye-opener. I would recommend this book to anyone trying to improve their basic personal relations skills.
Full of useful advice to develop good interpersonal relations. Must read it again after some time to see how much I could gain from it.

There was a distant era when common sense was more or less, well, common. How to Win Friends and Influence People is like a lost dispatch from that long ago time. It is complete with delightfully archaic second-hand testimonials from people like Ebenezer Whooping Cough of the Long Island Buggy-Whip Company. A star of Sharknado 2 named Wil Wheaton boiled the book down to a core statement, Don't Be a Dick.The book does contain some basic truths about listening, kindness and consideration. Those notes should ring true in any era.

To summarize, 'be positive and non-confrontational'. There was something comforting in reading this book, that sense of nostalgia, that sort of '... things were sure simpler back then yet still never change' feel to the anecdotes. It's the kind of feeling you get when you see an old, black and white news reel. Every example of 'Joe, a Department Head at Acme Inc.' reminded me of the office in the movie, 'The Apartment' - those neatly aligned rows of desks each with a typewriter and the same neatly dressed worker bees. Anyway, I think the advise was worthy and I plan to review the points and try to follow them.
I have read this numerous times, but it is always a good read and reminder

A good book full of timeless wisdom, yet obviously written for a different era. If only schools taught these rules of thumb in human relationships instead of the self-esteem movement!

Extraordinary !! Though this book was written in early 1930's or may be before but the authors understanding of human behavior and their apt nature is astonishing. This book is a bestselling classic for a reason-the principles taught really work. The sum of the book is this: To better lead, change, and influence people, you must make them feel important. Giving sincere praise, admitting your own mistakes when your trying to point out something in a person you want to change, etc. The book is very helpful.

No matter your age, profession, or stage in life i think everyone should read this book. So much good advice on how to deal with people. Everything in here makes so much sense and really helps to give some insight into what makes some more successful than others. Definitely recommend.

Not many things in this world would stand true after almost a century. This is one of those books where the thoughts and ideas still remain pertinent to this day. According to me, every college student should read this book, if not present in their curriculum. This book teaches us how to really face the challenges of the corporate world and remain influential to get your ideas and thoughts through.

There are several ways to read this book one of which is that in essence, human beings are a self-involved race. We like to hear the sound of our own name and don’t care much about anything else unless it affects us directly. Another way is that people are generally good but sometimes we need to be carefully made aware of other avenues that benefit not just themselves, but someone else as well.Two sides, one coin. Smile. Don’t talk about you, talk about them and how your idea/product etc. will benefit them. There are many principles that Dale Carnegie lists after each major portion of this book. All principles are sound and there is a reason that this book has been in print for so long. Do yourself a favour and read this book if you are having problems dealing with people in general. If nothing else, it is good food for thought.
Still effective after all these years!!!!!
